content: One important metric to look for in a stock is an 80 or higher Relative Strength Rating. Motorola Solutions (MSI) cleared that benchmark Wednesday, with a jump from 78 to 81 Wednesday. X When you're researching the best stocks to buy and watch, keep a close on eye on relative price strength.This exclusive rating from Investor's Business Daily tracks price action with a 1 (worst) to 99 (best) score. The rating shows how a stock's price performance over the last 52 weeks compares to all the other stocks in our database. History reveals that the top-performing stocks typically have an RS Rating north of 80 in the early stages of their moves.Looking For The Best Stocks To Buy And Watch? Start HereMotorola Solutions is still inside a buy range after climbing above a 112.01 buy point in a flat base. Once a stock moves 5% or higher beyond the initial entry, it's considered out of a proper buy zone. Top and bottom line growth moved higher last quarter. Earnings were up 55%, compared to 3% in the prior report. Revenue increased from 4% to 15%. Motorola Solutions holds the No. 2 rank among its peers in the Telecom-Consumer Products industry group. Apple (AAPL) is the top-ranked stock within the group.Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Taser maker Axon Enterprise (AAXN) saw its stock soared more than 20% Wednesday after the firm reported stunning results that crushed expectations.XThe firm, which also makes Axon body cameras, reported a 243% EPS increase to 24 cents, while Wall Street had expected a first-quarter loss of 4 cents a share, according to Zacks Investment Research. Revenue increased 16% to $101 million, above views for $92 million.Software and sensors revenue, which includes Axon body cameras, jumped 75% to $37.7 million, and Axon Cloud revenue shot up 72% to $20.2 million. Taser weapons revenue  increased 10% to $63.5 million.The company also booked $98 million in software and sensors orders as more law enforcement agencies adopt body cameras in response to police shootings.The surprise earnings come hot on the heels of the company's announcement that it is acquiring its biggest bodycam rival VIEVU for $4.6 million in cash and $2.5 million in stock. The subsidiary of Safariland Group adds five new major city customers for Axon.Axon shares were up 22% to 54.62 on the stock market today, well extended from a shallow 39-week cup-with-handle base, MarketSmith analysis shows. It had an entry of 28.06, and broke out in low volume on Feb. 15. The stock finally followed through with a big move in high volume on Feb. 28, following Q4 results.Among other makers of body cameras, Motorola Solutions (MSI) fell 1.9%, GoPro (GPRO) rallied 0.35%, and Digital Ally (DGLY) was down 2%.In addition, the company raised its full-year revenue growth guidance to 18%-20%, up from a prior view of 16%-18%, and above consensus views for a 17% gain."Our strategic growth areas are TASER weapons, Sensors hardware including on-officer body cameras and Axon Fleet in-car video systems, our Evidence.com connected software network and Axon Records and Computer Aided Dispatch software," CEO Rick Smith said in a press release. "On the bottom line, we are right-sizing our investments to match the opportunity set and continuing to work toward delivering break-even operating margins in our Software & Sensors segment by the end of 2020."Acquiring VIEVU is positive for Axon, as VIEVU managed to beat the market leader for a number of large contracts, including tie-ups with the New York Police Department, the Miami-Dade Police Department, and the Phoenix Police Department.YOU MAY ALSO BE INTERESTED IN:This Stun Gun Maker Is Cashing In On The Police Bodycam BoomWorth Surveilling: This Police Bodycam Maker's Stock Is SoaringStill Bullish On Bitcoin? Look for the stock to create a new chance to get in like a three-weeks tight or pullback to the 50-day or 10-week line. Motorola Solutions posted 3% EPS growth in the latest quarterly report, while sales growth came in at 4%. Motorola Solutions earns the No. 1 rank among its peers in the Telecom-Consumer Products industry group. Investors hopped back into stocks today even after a U.S. government official told Bloomberg there's a 99% chance that the U.S. on Friday will start imposing tariffs on billions of dollars' worth of Chinese products. Apple helped the Nasdaq pace the major indexes with a nearly 1.1% gain as of 3:45 p.m. ET, while the S&P 500 was not far behind, rising more than 0.8%.At 2736, the S&P 500 is up 2.3% since Jan. 1, following a 19.4% lift in 2017.The Nasdaq, at 7585, has advanced 9.9% year to date. In 2017, the premier index for growth companies vaulted 28.2% higher.Apple (AAPL), up 9.4% for the year, as well as chip companies spearheaded the Nasdaq's outperformance. The iPhone, iPad and digital services titan rallied nearly 0.9% and is holding up above its rising 50-day moving average, a good sign for the bulls.The megacap tech, which sports a $911 billion market cap, stands 3.6% above the 179.04 buy point in a seven-week double bottom. Apple initially broke out on May 4, thrusting nearly 4% higher in volume that jumped 61% above the 50-day average.Therefore, Apple stands within the important 5% buy zone.Also watch for a potential base on base to also possibly form.Apple sports a decent Relative Price Strength Rating of 79 on a scale of 1 to 99, according to IBD Stock Checkup. That scores trails industry compatriots Roku (ROKU), Ooma (OOMA) and Motorola Solutions (MSI) within IBD's Telecom-Consumer Products industry group.Roku went public at 14 a share on Sept. 28 last year, then rocketed out of a first-stage IPO base at 29.90 six weeks later. That breakout yielded a solid gain of 96%.Roku peaked a 58.80, then dived into its current cup-type base.While the Los Gatos, Calif., company shows formidable revenue growth (up 29% in 2017 to $513 million), Roku is not expected to go fully into the black until 2019. It's expected to lose 29 cents a share this year, then earn 5 cents a share next year.Apple, in turn, continues to forge a path of growth acceleration.The Street sees earnings climbing 31% to $2.18 a share in the June-ended fiscal third quarter. That would exceed its year-over-year increases of 11%, 18%, 24%, 16% and 30% in the prior five quarters.Apple's revenue, driven in large part by fantastic growth of digital services and brand-new product innovations such as the cellular-ready Apple Watch, is seen rising 15% to $52.3 billion.The Dow Jones industrial average lagged the other main indexes, rising 0.7%. The S&P SmallCap 600 rallied 0.8%.Top industry groups of the day not only included the chip sector. While some defensive areas of the market, such as dairy products, confectionery foods, meat and household appliances, all rose sharply, steel production, tires, solar, movie and steel alloy firms also gained 1.9% or higher.At least nine of the 30 components in the Dow industrial average have gained 1 point or more, including chipmaking giant Intel (INTC). The stock rallied nearly 2% to 50.42 in below-average trade and lies 12% below a 52-week peak of 57.60.The member of IBD's semiconductor manufacturing industry group is caught in a type of "no man's land," chart-wise. As seen in a daily chart, the stock has fallen well below its 50-day moving average. That triggered a sell signal for recent new investors. However, Intel is also keeping an air cushion above the long-term 200-day moving average. That signals the stock's long-term run is not over.Please go to the charts in MarketSmith to see both the 50- and 200-day moving averages in action.For now, keep watching how the stock acts and see if it has the strength to build a new base and thus furnish a new correct buy opportunity.Second-quarter results look positive. The Street sees Intel's earnings galloping 32% higher to 95 cents a share on a 13% increase in sales to $16.69 billion. In the first quarter, Intel grew EPS 32% and the top line 9%.Datacenter revenue has become an ever more important part of the business pie for Intel.ASML (ASML), a lithography systems expert and member of the chip equipment group, has performed in a similar fashion technically. The Dutch giant, up 2.2% to 195.85, is sandwiched in between its 50- and 200-day lines. However, the stock lies just 9% below a 216.90 all-time peak.Earnings at ASML grew 74%, 115%, 34%, 46%, 39% and 38% vs. year-ago levels in the past six quarters. Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters see earnings up just 4% in Q2 to $1.28 a share.In other financial markets, crude oil dropped hard as Iran reportedly told President Trump to stop tweeting about energy prices. WTI near-term futures fell 1.3% to $73.16 a barrel. At that level, however, WTI is down less than 3% from its 52-week peak of $75.27.The yield on the benchmark U.S. Treasury 10-year bond(Please follow Saito-Chung on Twitter at @IBD_DChung for more analysis of growth stocks, charts, buy points, sell signals and financial markets.)RELATED:Inside Investor's Corner: When To Take Losses In A Stock At Smaller Than 8%Which Way Is The Stock Market Headed? Over the last three months, the top-performing mutual funds have been heavily buying shares in big-name industry leaders, including Bank of America (BAC), Intel (INTC), Boeing (BA), Abbott Laboratories (ABT) and Charles Schwab (SCHW), investing well over $1 billion in each during that period.X BofA led the group, with top fund managers scooping up more than $2 billion of the financial giant's shares. Boosted by that demand, the stock is now around 25% above the 25.45 buy point it cleared in September.Semiconductor equipment maker Applied Materials (AMAT) and software and analytics leader Adobe (ADBE) both came in just shy of the $1 billion mark, getting investments of approximately $982 million and $932 million, respectively.The IBD 50 screen identifies the top growth stocks that are strongly displaying the key traits typically shared by the biggest stock market winners.Seven of the names on this month's list of new buys by top funds are also currently on the IBD 50, including Applied Materials, Adobe, Abiomed (ABMD), Lam Research (LRCX) and S&P Global (SPGI).Get these newsletters delivered to your inbox & more info about our products & services. Privacy Policy & Terms of UseIn addition to BofA, seven other bank stocks made the list, joined by six financial sector companies, including Charles Schwab, which was named one of the best online stock brokers for 2018.Leading portfolio managers also continued to pick up shares in semiconductor stocks, including the aforementioned Intel, Applied Materials and Lam Research, as well as Microsemi (MSCC) and KLA Tencor (KLAC).Portfolio managers also showed a healthy interest in medical stocks, with five companies from that sector joining Abiomed and Abbot Laboratories on the list, including Express Scripts (ESRX) and Cantel Medical (CMD).Just because mutual fund managers have been buying a stock doesn't mean it's time for individual investors to pick up shares, especially given that the overall market has come under selling pressure recently. Be sure to run all your stock ideas through a buying checklist and do additional research before making any investment decisions.On Tuesday, Applied Materials cleared a 58.83 buy point in a later-stage, and therefore riskier, double bottom. Its relative strength line has been trending sharply higher and is just shy of new high ground.Lam Research is also working on a late-stage double bottom, and has now climbed within 5% of the 218.58 entry.Scanning and tracking solutions leader Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) leapt past a buy point in January, but pulled back as the stock market fell sharply in early February. But on Feb. 22, Zebra soared on its Q4 earnings report and is now 27% above the initial 112.49 entry.Adobe also launched a successful breakout in January and has now climbed 14% above the 186.37 buy point.IBD 50 member SVB Financial (SIVB), which owns Silicon Valley Bank and was just featured in the IBD Stock Analysis, broke out past a 263.19 entry on Tuesday, but is now testing support at the buy point after the resignation of Donald Trump's top economic advisor Gary Cohn rattled the market.Despite being among the top new buys this month, Boeing topped the list of stocks being sold, with 42 net sellers (123 funds selling minus 81 buying).American Express (AXP) was second, with 40 net sellers (90 funds selling minus 50 buying).Managed care provider Humana (HUM) and Motorola Solutions (MSI) also saw a significant number of net sellers.You May Also Like:What Are Today's Fastest-Growing Companies?Find And Track The Best Mutual FundsVideo: How To Quickly Find Top-Performing Mutual Funds

Asset-tracking firm Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) on Tuesday posted better-than-expected results for the third quarter and guided above consensus estimates for the current quarter.XZebra earned an adjusted $1.87 a share, up 31% year over year, on sales of $935 million, up 3%, in the September quarter. Analysts expected earnings of $1.73 a share on sales of $915 million.For the current quarter, Zebra expects to earn an adjusted $2.10 a share, up 9%, on sales of $986.5 million, up 5%, based on the midpoint of its guidance. Wall Street was modeling $2.08 and $961 million.Lincolnshire, Ill.-based Zebra makes rugged mobile computers, bar code scanners, and bar code printers enhanced with software and services to enable real-time enterprise visibility of inventory and other assets.But Zebra shares tumbled 5.6% to close at 109.31 on the stock market today. The stock broke out of a 16-week flat base with a buy point of 109.40 on Sept. 28.IBD'S TAKE: Zebra Technologies stock has an IBD Composite Rating of 92, meaning it has outperformed 92% of stocks in key metrics over the past 12 months. For more analysis on Zebra, visit the IBD Stock Checkup."Looking ahead to Q4, we expect strong operating performance and free cash flow to enable at least $300 million of debt paydown for the year,"  Zebra Chief Executive Anders Gustafsson said in a news release. "We continue to advance our Enterprise Asset Intelligence strategy through our leading portfolio of innovative products and Savanna, our (Internet of Things) data intelligence platform."Zebra has been working to reduce its debt load, lowering its interest costs, Gustafsson said.Zebra is paring down debt that it took on when it acquired the enterprise business of Motorola Solutions (MSI) in October 2014 for $3.45 billion in cash. That deal was funded with $200 million of cash on hand and $3.25 billion in new debt.In an interview with Investor's Business Daily, Gustafsson said he was baffled by the stock's reaction to Zebra's earnings report."We beat practically every metric," Gustafsson said. "We had better revenue, better profit, and we beat the outlook. The share price has run up quite a bit this year, so maybe the expectations were for even better numbers. I'm not quite sure."Retail and health care were the strongest vertical markets for Zebra's products last quarter, Gustafsson said. Retail is the company's largest vertical and health care is its smallest, but fastest-growing segment."We had a very strong quarter and had great momentum overall," he said. "We had broad-based growth across all our regions and all of our major product lines. We saw margin expansion and strong earnings-per-share growth."RELATED:Zebra Technologies Beats Second-Quarter Targets, Guides Higher

AT&T (T) warned Tuesday that any states opting out of its FirstNet contract with the federal government must ensure that alternate public safety network providers — such as Verizon Communications (VZ) — have services totally "interoperable" with its FirstNet system.XSpeaking at a Goldman Sachs technology conference, AT&T Chief Executive Randall Stephenson said: "There's a lot of complexity in terms of how someone else would come in and compete here. We like where we are in this process."AT&T in late March won a contract to build out FirstNet, the federal government's nationwide wireless broadband network dedicated to public safety. AT&T in June sent out its proposal to 50 states.About 20 states have agreed to use the FirstNet network AT&T is building. States have until year-end to decide whether to go with AT&T or another company.Verizon in August announced plans to build a network dedicated to public safety communications but will not receive federal funding like AT&T.Without mentioning Verizon directly, Stephenson said rival networks "need to be fully interoperable with the AT&T core — fully interoperable," so that emergency personnel do not encounter problems.Verizon controls two-thirds of the market for emergency personnel, says an Oppenheimer report. "We expect the company is aiming to maintain its market share" by announcing a rival to FirstNet, said Tim Horan, an Oppenheimer analyst in the report.Stephenson, though, said AT&T is in a good position "to take significant share" in the "municipalities and state first-responder communities."AT&T is building a nationwide ground network, with backup generators and a dedicated security operations center as part of the FirstNet contract.Congress has set aside a $6.5 billion subsidy for the contract winner to design and build out the network. It's expected that AT&T will spend about $40 billion over the life of the deal to build, deploy, operate and maintain the network.AT&T stock rose 1.45% to close at 36.26 in the stock market today. Shares in Verizon climbed 1.1% to 46.79.IBD'S TAKE:  AT&T stock is down nearly 15% in 2017 as it awaits approval of its Time Warner acquisition. Verizon and AT&T are sometimes popular with investors looking for high dividends, but there are other options, such as banks, industrials and real estate investment trusts (REITs). Check out IBD's Income Investor.As part of the contract, AT&T will gain access to a swath of 20 MHz of spectrum in the 700 MHz frequency band for the life of the 25-year contract. While the FirstNet public safety network would be prioritized for emergency responders, the winning bidder would also be able to use the spectrum for commercial purposes and consumer services, considered highly valuable.Stephenson said the FirstNet contract will enable AT&T to create a "dense spectrum portfolio." AT&T partners to deploy FirstNet includes Motorola Solutions (MSI), General Dynamics (GD)) Sapient Consulting and Inmarsat Government.RELATED:How A Cellular Apple Watch Could Boost AT&T, Verizon, T-Mobile, SprintThree Reasons Why Telecom Merger Party On Hold: Goldman SachsComcast Hit On Video Subscriber Loss: Hurricane, Discounts Take Toll

X Video game maker Activision Blizzard (ATVI) scored with price target hikes after posting first-quarter earnings, biotech Celgene (CELG) was downgraded,  Zillow's (ZG) price target was hiked on stronger-than-expected Q1 earnings, and Lumentum Holdings (LITE) downgraded despite speculation over Apple (AAPL) contract win.Jefferies hiked its price target on the video game publisher to 68 from 55; Piper Jaffray upped its PT to 60 from 55.Activision Blizzard late Thursday reported  first-quarter sales and earnings that topped estimates. Activision's Q2 revenue forecast topped views but its EPS outlook was below expectations."Activision posted another huge beat with key games like Overwatch driving robust growth of in-game spending. The impressive performance comes despite investor fears that weak frontline holiday sales of Call of Duty would translate into weak first-half 2017 performance," said Timothy O'Shea, a Jefferies analyst in a report.Shares in Activision Blizzard rose 1.4% to 53.83 on the stock market today.RELATED:Activision Blizzard Beats Q1 Sales, Earnings TargetsRBC Capital its price target on the online real estate website to 48 from 40, Canaccord Genuity upped its PT to 46 from 42, and Cowen & Co. to 40 from 37. Zillow late Thursday reported EPS of 11 cents on revenue of $245.8 million, topping expectations.Zillow stock shot up 9.3% to 43.97.RELATED:Universal Display, Zillow Beat, Guide High; Impinj, Veeco Guide LowArgus Research downgraded the biomedical company to hold from buy. Celegene stock sank 1.65% to 122.41 Friday.RELATED:Biotech Surge: How To Survive In A Volatile MarketCitigroup upped its price target on Arista Networks, a rival of Cisco Systems (CSCO), to 165 from 150 following its Q1 earnings. Needham & Co. hiked its PT to 162 from 150.Arista late Thursday reported adjusted first-quarter earnings that topped views. Arista said EPS minus items were 93 cents a share, up 37% from a year ago, with revenue rising 38% to $335.5 million.Arista stock rose 3.2% to 144.72 after tumbling to 135.21 earlier.RELATED:Arista Networks Earnings Top Views; Revenue Outlook Light?Northland downgraded the maker of fiber optic components to market perform after it slashed revenue guidance for fiscal Q4 on weak demand from China. Tim Savageaux, a Northland analyst set a price target of 50. Even if Lumentum wins orders for 3D sensors from smartphone makers such as Apple, Savageaux says weakening demand from China is a worry for Lumentum. Lumentum  stock advanced 5.2% to 49.45 on Friday after popping 9% on Thursday.RELATED:Lumentum Has Apple iPhone 3D Sensor Design Win In The Bag: AnalystIn other analyst moves, Barclays increased the price target of Ansys (ANSS) to 115 from 96, RBC Capital cut CBS (CBS) price target to 75 from 78, and Baird downgraded Akamai Technologies (AKAM) to neutral.Canaccord Genuity upped the price target of Universal Display (OLED) to 90 from 65, Citigroup increased the price target of Motorola Solutions (MSI) to 102 from 93, and Jefferies hiked Varonis (VRNS)  to 41 from 37.RELATED:These 3 Software Makers Broke Out To Buys, But With A Design Flaw

BlackBerry (BBRY) is finally starting to look like a real software company.After three years of acquisitions, layoffs and trying to convince customers it could do more than build smartphones, the Canadian company's software revenue and profit margins are growing in the way Chief Executive Officer John Chen wants them to.BlackBerry surpassed its target of $640 million in software revenue for fiscal 2017, the company announced Friday, achieving Chen's goal of increasing sales from that division by 30% in the year. It posted profit of 4 cents a share, beating out the highest estimate from analysts, and said it would be profitable for its entire fiscal 2018, which began this month. Gross margins were around 60%, moving toward Chen's goal of hitting 80% a year from now, the company said in a statement Friday.Shares jumped 11.5% to 7.75 on the stock market today. BlackBerry hit 8.09 intraday, a six-month high.BlackBerry shed the burden of its ever-shrinking phone business by officially outsourcing all device design, production and sales to other companies last year. The firm has also been moving into software for self-driving automobiles and has a formal partnership with Ford Motor (F) involving in-car connectivity. Earlier this week, Ford agreed to hire 400 of BlackBerry's mobile tech experts to work on connected cars.IBD'S TAKE: BlackBerry hasn't been a relevant force in tech for several years now, hitting its peak of 148.13 in June 2008 and precipitously diving in 2011 thanks to Apple's (AAPL) smartphones. Maybe it can mount some sort of comeback but isn't even ranked in IBD's Telecom-Consumer Products Group. The top spot there goes to Motorola Solutions (MSI).Now the challenge is selling BlackBerry's suite of security-focused software products, which range from tools that help companies track their employees' mobile devices, to computer operating systems for guided missiles.In the fiscal fourth quarter, revenue was $297 million, beating the average estimate of $289 million. Software revenue was $182 million, 80% of which was recurring and not due to one-time licensing deals. Its cash balance increased, a key milestone after months of burning money, to $1.7 billion.

AT&T (T) did the expected Thursday and won the contract to build out FirstNet, the federal government's nationwide wireless broadband network dedicated to public safety.U.S. Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross made the announcement Thursday morning in Washington. Details of the agreement had yet to be ironed out, but AT&T will be the primary contractor responsible for adding towers and antennas to build out the vast network. AT&T said its "team" to deploy FirstNet includes Motorola Solutions (MSI), General Dynamics (GD), Sapient Consulting and Inmarsat Government.Congress has set aside $6.5 billion for the contract winner to design and build out the network. It's expected that AT&T will spend about $40 billion over the life of the deal to build, deploy, operate and maintain the network.As part of the contract, though, AT&T will gain access to a swath of 20 MHz of spectrum in the 700 MHz frequency band for the life of the 25-year contract. While the FirstNet public safety network would be prioritized for emergency responders, the winning bidder would also be able to use the spectrum for commercial purposes and consumer services, considered highly valuable.IBD'S TAKE: Shares in AT&T, which in October agreed to buy media giant Time Warner (TWX), are down about 2% in 2017. Rising interest rates are negative for high-dividend paying stocks, such as AT&T and Dow component Verizon Communications (VZ). Research other options at The Income Investor.AT&T beat out Rivada Networks, a consortium that includes wireless network makers Nokia (NOK) and Ericsson (ERICY) as well as chipmaker Intel (INTC), and Harris (HRS).Analysts say FirstNet's buildout should boost cell tower operators such as American Tower (AMT) and SBA Communications (SBAC).Shares of AT&T were up 0.8% to close at 41.76 on the stock market today.RELATED:Cell Tower Stocks Claw Back On Verizon-AT&T Unlimited-Data WarComcast, Charter Morphing Into Broadband-First Providers

Incyte's (INCY) oncology program will grow on a Merck (MRK) partnership tying Keytruda and epacadostat in four "hot" tumors in 2017, Leerink analyst Michael Schmidt said Friday as he boosted his price target on Incyte stock.Schmidt has an outperform rating on Incyte stock and upped his price target to 131 from 115 to reflect the epacadostat opportunity. On the stock market today, Incyte stock lifted a fraction to 117.75. Earlier, shares rose as much as 1.9% and neared a 15-month high achieved Tuesday.The announcement was made Monday during the annual JPMorgan Healthcare Conference in San Francisco. Merck and Incyte have tested their combo on nine types of tumors. Data in MSI-high colorectal cancer and diffuse large B-cell lymphoma are not yet available.Keytruda and epacadostat won't advance in ovarian cancer nor triple-negative breast cancer. But the duo will continue to work in melanoma, bladder, kidney, lung, head and neck cancers, according to the companies' announcement Monday.IBD'S TAKE: Donald Trump referred to the pharma industry as "disastrous" and accused it of "getting away with murder." His comments overlapped with the annual JPMorgan Healthcare Conference in San Francisco, where the tone was seen as "cautiously optimistic."

Schmidt is bullish on Incyte's epacadostat opportunity. Phase 3 trials with Keytruda are likely to begin later this year. Thus far, the data have been "unambiguous" and researchers from both companies are comfortable with moving forward.Epacadostat belongs to a class of drugs that inhibit IDO1, a gene. IDO molecules are thought to allow tumor cells to escape detection by the immune system. Researchers are testing whether inhibiting the gene could assist in battling certain cancers.Questions remain as to the extent of the partnership, Schmidt said."It is unclear whether Merck will opt-in to co-fund the planned trials and whether a period of exclusivity will be granted to Merck before Incyte may initiate additional phase three trials in potentially overlapping indications with another PD1 inhibitor," he wrote in a note.Merck is also working with Eli Lilly (LLY) in combining Keytruda and the chemotherapy Alimta to treat non-small cell lung cancer. The opportunity for epacadostat is NSCLC depends on a development strategy and competition, Schmidt said.But Merck is well-positioned in the market. It will likely beat rivals Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) and AstraZeneca (AZN) to the market with an immuno-oncology plus chemo treatment. Analysts note that Bristol-Myers could creep up on Merck with an IO plus IO combo.Merck stock rose a fraction Friday, rising 3.7% for the week.RELATED:Eli Lilly Rebounds On Chemo-Drug Patent Win Vs. Generic Teva

AT&T (T) appears likely to win the federal contract award for FirstNet, the federal government's plan to create a nationwide wireless broadband network dedicated to public safety, analysts say, a development that would have ramifications for Verizon Communications (VZ), T-Mobile US (TMUS), Comcast (CMCSA) and others taking part in a government auction of TV airwaves.As part of the FirstNet contract, AT&T would gain access to a swath of 20 MHz of spectrum, giving it less reason to bid aggressively in the TV spectrum auction, says Jonathan Chaplin, an analyst at New Street Research.And while it's unclear if that's what happened, the FCC on Monday, in its latest bidding stage in the auction, said total bids came to only $19.7 billion, where broadcasters had recently lowered the asking price to $40.3 billion. Now, broadcasters will need to decide by mid-December whether to lower their asking price yet again."With AT&T gaining access to 20 MHz of low-band spectrum via FirstNet, we suspect that (AT&T's) interest in similar low-band spectrum in the 600 MHz (TV) auction will now be diminished," Chaplin wrote in a research report.While Chaplin says other registered spectrum bidders — such as Verizon, T-Mobile and Comcast — could step up and bid for more airwaves, another possibility is that TV broadcasters could walk away from the auction if they deem total bids as insufficient.IBD'S TAKE: A successful auction is important to T-Mobile, which analysts say is most in need of more airwaves. T-Mobile stock is up nearly 40 . Dish Network stock has been in a trading range since the auction started in March. Learn more about Comcast, another registered bidder, at IBD Stock CheckupThe National Association of Broadcasters had a cryptic initial response to Monday's event."The results of the latest round of the TV auction leave us scratching our heads, given the decade-long refrain of a spectrum crunch," NAB CEO Gordon Smith said in a statement. "We look forward to the next round."As regards FirstNet, AT&T appears to have beat out Rivada Networks, a consortium that includes wireless network makers Nokia (NOK) and Ericsson (ERICY) as well as Intel Security, part of chipmaker Intel (INTC), and Harris (HRS), although Rivada has mounted a legal challenge, says Chaplin."We now believe that FirstNet will delay the announcement until after the Rivada court case has run its course, likely around March of 2017," said Chaplin.Tim Long, analyst at BMO Capital Markets, agrees that AT&T is the FirstNet front-runner."AT&T has disclosed a number of updates regarding the FirstNet bidding process," said Long in a report. "The company believes it is the only bidder remaining in the 'competitive range' of the process, as rival Rivada was deemed outside this range for the contract.""After pdvWireless (PDVW) dropped out of the FirstNet bidding process in October 2016, we believed AT&T and Rivada were the two remaining bidders," Long wrote. "As Motorola Solutions (MSI) was not listed in the extensive list of partners to Rivada, we believed Motorola Solutions may be a likely partner to AT&T."If AT&T wins the FirstNet contract, "We believe it is unlikely the carrier would participate in the broadcaster auction in a meaningful way," said Mike McCormack, a Jefferies analyst, in a report Monday. "As such, we see downside to our initial $30 billion carrier demand estimate, which could also delay the auction timing. We had anticipated around $9 billion in spend from AT&T, implying adjusted demand in the low-$20-billion range ex-AT&T, not far from the current $19.7 billion offered in stage 3."Whoever wins the FirstNet contract would need to invest in network infrastructure. Congress has set aside 20 MHz of spectrum in the "D block" of the 700 MHz frequency band for the public safety network. While the FirstNet public safety network would be prioritized for emergency responders, the winning bidder would also be able to use the spectrum for commercial purposes and consumer services.According to an October Wells Fargo report, "barring a national emergency, we estimate the spectrum will be less than 1 ted by public safety needs, which provides the (FirstNet) winner with access to that excess capacity."In the TV airwaves auction, broadcasters just last week again reduced their asking price for prime wireless airwaves, this time to $40.3 billion. In two earlier rounds, TV broadcasters initially sought $86 billion for 100 megahertz of usable radio spectrum, then dropped their asking price to $54.6 billion for 90 MHz. If bidders agree to pay at least $40.3 billion combined, that would open up 80 MHz of airwaves for mobile video and other data services.If the TV spectrum is scuttled, that would be a plus for satellite TV broadcaster Dish Network (DISH), analysts say. Dish Network has some 77 MHz of airwaves and has been looking for a wireless partner.AT&T stock rose 2 cents in the stock market today to 38.63 and is trading just above the key 50-day moving average support line. Dish Network stock rose 2% to 56.66. It's near a possible 59.67 buy point out of a flat base.RELATED:T-Mobile, Dish Stakes High In TV Spectrum Auction EndgameHow Verizon, Comcast, Dish, T-Mobile Figure In Telecom M&A ScenariosSpectrum Wild Cards May Add Supply, Impact Verizon, T-Mobile, AT&T

When Motorola split its business in 2011, Motorola Mobility was viewed as the one with more potential. Google Inc., now known as Alphabet (GOOGL), apparently agreed when it bought the mobile handset business for $12.5 billion. At the time, the goal was to take on Apple (AAPL) in the smartphone market, but it never panned out. In 2014, Google sold…

In recent years, no industry has provided shareholder activists with as many opportunities to force changes -- or generate financial gains -- as technology.In its Shareholder Activism 2015 report issued last November, Moody's found that 33% of the 178 shareholder activism cases it had tracked through Oct. 15 of last year focused on tech firms, far more than any other industry.Tech firms, ironically, can blame their successes as well as their failures for their preferred status among shareholder activists. The sector's growth potential attracts the hedge funds and equity investors that are less inclined to sit docilely on the sidelines."You really have to have a stomach for it," said Gerry Granovsky, an analyst at bond rating firm Moody's Investor Service. "A lot of it is confrontational. You have to not be afraid to ruffle feathers."Where many of the most famous shareholder activism cases have focused on poorly managed companies that represented turnaround opportunities -- which does include a fair number of tech companies, to be sure -- many tech firms instead have been targeted for not sharing their riches enough.Granovsky points out that as the tech sector has demonstrated historic stability over the past 10 years, it has enjoyed growing access to debt. Meanwhile, as scores of tech firms have grown into thriving global businesses, many have amassed massive amounts of cash overseas and have chosen to keep it there rather than pay U.S. tax rates.It's that cash, and companies' explanations for hording it, that often attracts the attention of shareholder activists more than anything."Activists don't care about policies. They see Apple having $216 billion in cash," Granovsky said. "To some extent they have a point."The activities of shareholder activists do at least potentially benefit a larger group of stakeholders, and shareholder activists do function as a sort of corporate watchdog, so they have to be willing to get dirty for the cause.After finding itself on the receiving end of pressure from big-name shareholder activists Carl Icahn and David Einhorn, Apple (AAPL) has in the past couple of years been returning cash to shareholders in programmatic fashion.Similarly, persistent pressure from activists helped spur ATM maker NCR (NCR) to embark on an effort to buy back $1 billion worth of stock, funded by a deal with Blackstone that gives the financial advisory firm three seats on NCR's board -- a deal activist investor and NCR shareholder P. Schoenfeld Asset Management has questioned.Targeting excess cash is not a new shareholder activism strategy. In fact, it appears to have been one of the original strategies.In his just released book, "Dear Chairman: Boardroom Battles and the Rise of Shareholder Activism," Jeff Gramm, a portfolio manager and adjunct professor at Columbia Business School, traces shareholder activism back to the 1920s. Gramm explores a 1927 case in which economist and investor Benjamin Graham, considered the father of value investing, led an effort to get Northern Pipeline to release some of its stockpile of unused cash back to its shareholders.That strategy has been used against tech firms to great effect in recent years, with a number of companies succumbing to similar pressures. And Granovsky says that trend might not peak until interest rates rise, causing tech firms to slow their borrowing and instead start tapping those overseas cash reserves.No worries. Even if all the cash-rich tech companies start giving back to shareholders, there are always underperformers to turn around.Despite the stability in the tech market Granovsky points to, there are plenty of tech companies that have found themselves in activists' cross-hairs for other reasons. In 2013, Microsoft (MSFT) granted its first board seat to an activist -- ValueAct Capital -- after facing widespread criticism for being a step behind a series of emerging tech trends such as cloud computing and mobility.Last year, Qualcomm (QCOM) launched a "strategic realignment plan" after activist hedge fund Jana Partners began pressuring the company to spin off its struggling chip business from its profitable licensing business. Also last year, eBay (EBAY) spun off PayPal (PYPL) after pressure to do so from several activists, led by Icahn, who argued that both companies would perform better if separated.More recently, Yahoo (YHOO) has been girding itself for a battle with one of its biggest shareholders, activist Starboard Value, as the Internet giant has been unable to forge much revenue growth in the past decade.Consider the case of Motorola Solutions (MSI). Shareholder activists have besieged the company since 2007, when its former entity, Motorola, was embroiled in a series of legal skirmishes over allegations the company had made misleading financial statements. (It eventually split into two companies in 2011, establishing Motorola Solutions as a communications provider, while it spun off the cellphone business into a separate company, Motorola Mobility, acquired by Google in 2011 and then sold to China's Lenovo in 2014.)Between 2007 and 2015, Motorola granted board seats to shareholder activists Icahn and ValueAct, and also to private-equity firm Silver Lake Partners.Shep Dunlap, an investor relations spokesman at Motorola Solutions, spoke with IBD about the company's experience with ValueAct, describing the relationship as "generally collaborative" and nothing like the contentious battles for which other shareholder activists, such as Icahn, have become known."Their approach has been much more constructive with management rather than using the press and media as a mouthpiece," says Dunlap said.He says ValueAct's objectives have been aligned with Motorola's leadership from the get-go, and that ValueAct's guidance has helped streamline the company. In particular, he cites more than $550 million in costs removed since 2012, and $12 billion returned to shareholders, mostly through stock buybacks."There's been a lot of progress in terms of optimizing our cost structure," Dunlap said. "We're really a pure-play mission-critical communications company at this point."Naturally, ValueAct has profited from the relationship, and today still owns 4.7% of the company's stock, a stake worth about $619 million based on the current valuation of $13.2 billion.Dunlap points to the fact that ValueAct has been a Motorola shareholder since 2011, longer than most activists stick around, as evidence of its commitment to the company's long-term health. He said not every activist is out to create a firestorm, cash out, and move on."You have to keep an open mind when you're learning about an investor, whether it's an activist or not," he said. "I think every company should use the feedback that's available to them from the investor community."Its unlikely that the relationship has been as Pollyannaish as Dunlap paints it. Granovsky stopped short of describing shareholder activism as bullying, but was comfortable calling it intimidation."Companies don’t want to deal with activists," he said.That said, there are times when they're a necessary evil if a company is to thrive, and Motorola may be an example of this.One thing is certain: Shareholder activists aren't going anywhere, and tech companies, and their piles of cash and occasional missteps, are clearly in their sights.

Stocks finished lower Wednesday, but good quarterly results from Whole Foods Market (WFM) and Tesla Motors (TSLA) after the close may help set a positive tone for Thursday's open.The Nasdaq fell 0.8%, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average each dropped 0.6%. Volume was lighter on both exchanges, according to preliminary data.Whole Foods reported earnings per share of 44 cents, three pennies better than a year earlier and more than analysts expected. Revenue came in a $3.7 billion vs. estimates of $3.74 billion.  Investors after hours focused on the earnings beat, bidding the stock higher.They did the same with Tesla, which reported a first-quarter loss of 57 cents a share. The Street expected a 58-cent loss. The company promised to deliver 20,000 cars in the second quarter. Tesla shares dropped 4% in the regular session after the announcement that two executives were leaving the company while investor Jim Chanos highlighted his case against the company.Former leader FleetCor (FLT) lost ground after hours. It scored an earnings beat with EPS of $1.53, three cents above estimates, but it missed on revenue and gave in-line guidance.Thursday before the open, the Labor Department is forecast to report jobless claims of 262,000 for the week ended April 30 vs. 257,000 the prior week.Companies reporting earnings Thursday include GoPro (GPRO), Regeneron (REGN), Square (SQ), Cerner (CERN) and Motorola Solutions (MSI).

Taser (TASR) on Thursday said it would send more than 2,000 Axon Body 2 cameras to the Chicago Police Department this year, the latest such order amid increased scrutiny and accusations of law-enforcement abuse.Chicago began a pilot program with Axon cameras early last year and equipped another 1,400 officers with them in November. It joined police departments in Los Angeles and London that collectively have ordered nearly 30,000 Axon body cameras.Chicago's latest order comes after Taser late Wednesday reported first-quarter earnings per share and sales that topped expectations.Still, the company said that operating margins could "experience more pressure" in the first half of this year and recover in the second. Company costs have risen amid expansions in staff and international operations in recent months.Taser shares closed up 3.7% in the stock market today, briefly retaking their 50-day line intraday before easing back below it. The stock has trended below its 200-day line since August, partly amid tepid guidance and mixed results, but it has recovered after investors reacted positively to the company's results in February.Shares of body-camera maker Digital Ally (DGLY) fell 1.4%. Motorola Solutions (MSI) and GoPro (GPRO), which also have cameras used by police, ended flat and down 6%, respectively.The Chicago order announced Thursday included 2,031 body cameras, 784 Taser X2 Smart Weapons and five years of unlimited space on Evidence.com, Taser's cloud-based evidence storage system that connects to other products it offers. Taser said that the weapons shipped in the first quarter and that the cameras would likely ship in Q2 and Q3.As with other industries, the devices law enforcement uses have become more connected, and agencies have increasingly shifted the way they manage information to the cloud.The Chicago Police Department said it was "nearly doubling" the smart weapons at its disposal, in part "because of the way they can now integrate with the rest of our technology.""Between the body cameras, smart weapons and other devices, there's a significant amount of digital evidence that needs to be managed, and we're looking forward to leveraging the Evidence.com secure cloud platform to seamlessly manage this data in a secure, scalable and efficient manner," Chicago Police Department Deputy Chief Jonathan Lewin said in a statement.Police departments say Taser's products increase transparency and help prevent officer injury, but others argue that there's still plenty of room for subjectivity in footage gleaned from body cameras.Some of the company’s bigger deals still face potential logistical and financial challenges.Taser in November said it won a bid to equip 22,000 London Metropolitan Police officers with body cameras.“They are an enormous agency in terms of the scale,” CEO Rick Smith said on a conference call Thursday. “And I’d say it’s largely internal planning, logistics. I’ve sat in some of the meetings where they're planning this rollout. It’s a big logistical lift for them.”What’s more, plans in Los Angeles to outfit 7,000 LAPD officers with Taser body cameras by year’s end have become mired in concerns about costs.

Taser (TASR) said Monday it's winning the "vast majority" of deals in the body camera and evidence management marketplace and that it would add sales staff to keep up.On a conference call, Taser management said additional sales representatives are needed to "ensure we are in front of every single agency that is making a purchasing decision."Taser expects operating expenses increase to $123 million-$128 million this year as it boosts staff. But bookings growth should outpace operating expense growth this year.Shares of Taser closed up 11% in the stock market today but still about 45% off their 52-week high.Fourth-quarter earnings per share of 9 cents was flat from a year earlier, but that still beat estimates for a decline to 4 cents per share. Revenue for the quarter rose 20% to $56 million, above forecasts for $50.72 million.Taser's results came as U.S. law enforcement faces intensifying scrutiny following high-profile allegations of abuse.Sales in the company's Axon body camera and evidence management division jumped 47%. But sales in body-worn camera hardware fell by $1.1 million due to the company's decision to delay shipments of its new Axon Body 2 camera until the first quarter in order to ensure the product was up to the company's standards.Bookings for Axon and Evidence.com jumped 82%.Taser has also been expanding internationally. The company in November said it won a bid to provide body cameras to officers in the London Metropolitan Police Service.Shares of rival Digital Ally (DGLY) finished 2.2% higher. Shares of camera-maker GoPro (GPRO), which has also tried to move into the security business, lost 3.4%. Motorola  Solutions (MSI), which rolled out its own body-camera systems last year, fell 1.8%.

The stock market has been looking healthier this week, and more leading stocks are breaking out to new highs. Time will tell whether they can hold or extend those gains.Motorola Solutions (MSI) cleared a 73.07 buy point Thursday in heavy trade, extending its advance for a third straight session. The stock surged 6% Tuesday after reporting Q4 results before the open. Earnings rose 26% to $1.58 a share, topping views by 16 cents and marking the consumer electronics maker's fourth straight quarter of 25% or better growth. Sales fell 8% to $1.7 billion, but also beat forecasts.An A- Accumulation/Distribution Rating and up-down volume ratio above the neutral 1.0 level point to recent demand for shares. Motorola's relative strength line is at multiyear highs, a bullish sign.Vista Outdoor (VSTO), a maker of eyewear, binoculars, rifles and ammunition, added 1% in average volume. The stock staged an upside reversal Wednesday, climbing past a 49.37 buy point intraday before settling for a near 1% gain below the entry. It extended its win streak for a ninth straight session and remains in buy range.The company said Thursday it's buying BRG Sports' Action Sports unit, which includes brands such as Bell and Giro. Vista also carries a positive Accumulation/Distribution grade and up-down volume ratio.Smith & Wesson (SWHC) is shaping the right side of a cup base with a 26.64 buy point. The stock is 7% off its Jan. 5 peak. It rallied as much as 39% to the high from a prior breakout past a 19.07 entry. The gun maker owns the top Composite and EPS ratings of 99 and 97, respectively, in its 32-stock Security/Safety group. A 99 Relative Strength Rating is also best in group.Also in the security group, Sturm Ruger (RGR) (92 Composite) broke out past a 66.96 handle buy point. The gun maker reported Q4 results well above views. Chief Executive Michael Fifer said on a conference call he expects gun demand to rise if a Democrat wins the presidential election.

Stocks stalled Friday, capping the week with the first sign of institutional selling since the market went into a confirmed uptrend. The Nasdaq inched up less than 0.2% Friday, while the S&P 500 subtracted less than 0.2%. Small caps did best, with the Russell 2000 gaining 0.5%. The IBD 50 fell 0.6%. Volume rose across the board. The day's action…

Stocks sank more than 1% Tuesday, erasing most of the prior day's gains, as oil prices fell and consumer confidence fell to a seven-month low.The Nasdaq dropped 1.5%, the S&P 500 lost 1.2% and the Dow Jones industrial average sank 1.1%. Volume was mixed in the stock market today, edging up 2% on the NYSE and dipping 1% on the Nasdaq compared to Monday, according to preliminary data.Crude prices remained volatile, sinking 5% following Monday's 6% gain. Oil producer Range Resources (RRC) plunged nearly 10%, leading the S&P 500 lower. JP Morgan (JPM) dropped 4% after saying it would set aside more money to cover expected losses on loans to energy companies hurt by the recent plunge in oil prices.Restaurant and telecom stocks were among the day's best performers.Texas Roadhouse (TXRH), a Kentucky-based operator of full-service restaurants, popped 13% after a better-than-expected quarterly earnings report. Volume was huge as the stock cleared a 40.92 buy point of a 30-week consolidation.The gain came despite a 5.6-point drop in the Conference Board's index of consumer confidence for February. The reading of 92.2 marked a seven-month low as consumers grew less optimistic about both current and future conditions.Motorola Solutions (MSI) soared 6% in huge volume after reporting that fourth-quarter profit rose 26% to $1.58 a share, easily beating Wall Street forecasts. Revenue slipped 8% to $1.68 billion.Analysts at Bernstein upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform on Wednesday, according to Briefing.comThe stock is approaching a 73.07 buy point of a 14-week consolidation. The highly rated Fidelity Contrafund (FCNTX) increased its holdings last quarter.

Stocks fell sharply and were close to session lows near midday Tuesday as investors weighed a big drop in consumer confidence.The Nasdaq lost 1.3%, the S&P 500 gave up 1.2%, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.1%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking very close to Monday's levels.In economic news, consumer confidence fell 5.6 points to a 92.2 reading in February, far below economists’ 97.2 forecast, the lowest reading since last July.Inside the Dow, JPMorgan (JPM) and Goldman Sachs (GS) lagged in the early going, down about 3% each.Among the Nasdaq 100, Baidu (BIDU) slumped 4% ahead of its earnings report, due Thursday after the close. Another China name, NetEase (NTES), reports Wednesday after the close. It slipped 2%. After recent pullbacks, both stocks are getting resistance at their 10-week moving averages.In the stock market today, Motorola Solutions (MSI) surged 7% after reporting earnings before the open. Revenue growth has declined for three straight quarters, but the stock looks poised to break out from a 14-week consolidation.Elsewhere, Fortune Brands (FBHS) reclaimed its 50-day moving average as it works on the right side of a potential base. Shares rallied 1.5%. The company showed three straight quarters of accelerating earnings and sales growth, and growth prospects look good with full-year profit expected to rise 20% this year and 17% in 2017.Ellie Mae (ELLI) rebounded nicely after Monday's reversal in heavy volume. Shares rose 3% in brisk trade. The fast-growing provider of electronic mortgage origination services is trying to clear a long base that started in August.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, West Texas Intermediate crude oil for April delivery slumped 5% to $31.77 a barrel.

Stocks rose Thursday, ending at session highs, as oil rallied and orders for long-lasting goods climbed.After a sluggish start, the Dow Jones industrial average rose 1.3%, the S&P 500 climbed 1.1%, and the Nasdaq added 0.9%. But volume fell sharply in the stock market today, sinking 41% on the Nasdaq and 17% on the NYSE compared to Wednesday, according to preliminary data.Motorola Solutions (MSI), which makes telecommunications equipment, rose 1.7% and cleared a 73.07 buy point in heavy volume. The breakout came two days after the stock jumped 6% following a better-than-expected earnings report.The stock's Relative Strength line is rising, which bodes well. The highly rated Fidelity Contrafund (FCNTX) boosted its position in Q4.Early Thursday, the Commerce Department reported that orders for durable goods rose 4.9% in January, which easily beat analysts' forecasts. The across-the-board gains bode well for the beaten-down manufacturing sector. Meanwhile, oil rose nearly 3%, topping $33 a barrel.Apparel manufacturers were among the day's best performers.Carter's (CRI), which makes children's apparel, gapped up and soared more than 12% after a better-than-expected quarterly earnings report. The stock has retaken its 40-day moving average as it works on a 31-week consolidation.Vince Holding (VNCE), a maker of apparel, footwear and handbags, rose more than 16%. But it's still more than 71% off a 52-week high amid sharp profit declines in the past two quarters.On the downside, Restoration Hardware (RH) plunged 26% to its lowest level since April 2013 after the luxury furniture retailer said profit for the latest quarter declined 3% to 99 cents a share, far below Wall Street estimates. Revenue rose 11% to $647.2 million, also well below forecasts.

Stocks stuck firmly to negative territory in afternoon trading Tuesday, rattled by several headlines, including a big drop in oil prices and weak consumer confidence data.The Nasdaq, S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average all fell 0.9%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking slightly higher than Monday's levels. If the percentage losses and volume holds on the stock market today, it would be the market's first distribution day since the Nasdaq confirmed a new uptrend last week.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, April crude oil fell nearly 5% to $31.82 a barrel, giving back nearly all of Monday's 6% gain.In economic news, consumer confidence fell to a 92.2 reading in February, far below economists’ 97.2 forecast, the lowest reading since last July. The 10-year Treasury yield rose as much as 4 basis points early in the session but reversed, falling 2 basis points to  1.73%.In earnings news, Fitbit (FIT) plunged 19%. The company reported another quarter of strong earnings and sales growth, but its Q1 guidance and user metrics disappointed.Among Nasdaq 100 names, Baidu (BIDU) slumped nearly 5% ahead of its earnings report, due Thursday after the close. Another China name, NetEase (NTES), reports Wednesday after the close. It slipped 1.5%. After recent pullbacks, both stocks are getting resistance at their 10-week moving averages.First Solar (FSLR) lost 3%. It's been trading around its 50-day moving average ahead of its earnings report after the close.Bright spots were few and far between in Tuesday's session, but Motorola Solutions (MSI) rocketed 6% after the company reported earnings. Earnings per share rose 26% from a year ago, marking the fourth straight quarter of 25%+ growth, but sales fell 8% to $1.68 billion. The stock is flirting with a breakout over a 73.07 buy point.

Genpact (G) has been one of the most resilient tech plays in the current jittery market. The stock is just below a potential buy point in an eleven-week-old flat base. Genpact is about as global as they come: incorporated in Bermuda, with its executive offices in New York, operations in 25 countries and the bulk of its 70,000 employees in…

The stock market gained altitude in afternoon trading Tuesday, as the main indexes rallied about 2% apiece.The Nasdaq led with a 2.2% vault, while the S&P 500 roared 1.9% higher, and the Dow Jones industrial average added 1.7%. Small caps lagged a little, as the Russell 2000 managed only a 1.3% advance.The Nasdaq was back above its 50-day moving average for the first time since the end of last year. The S&P 500 jumped right back above its own 50-day line.Volume was running sharply higher, an indication that institutional investors were embracing the rally heavily. Winners led losers by 4-to-1 on the NYSE and by 5-to-2 on the Nasdaq.Banking and heavy construction stocks led the market, aided by a solid construction spending report that showed a 1.5% increase for January, above expectations for a 0.5% improvement. The Institute for Supply Management’s manufacturing index rose in February, which also seemed to boost construction and financial stocks.In the finance sector, Citigroup (C), Morgan Stanley (MS) and Bank of America (BAC) were up more than 1% each. Those stocks are rising from lows made on Feb. 11 but remain well off 52-week highs.Auto sales in February were strong for most manufacturers, with Ford reporting a 20% leap in sales from the year-earlier period. Sales at General Motors (GM) fell 1.5%, and scandal-plagued Volkswagen (VLKAY) had a 13% drop in sales.Alphabet's (GOOGL) Google was one of the busiest stocks in the stock market today, trading about one-third more shares than it usually does at this time of day. The stock is fighting to climb back over the 50-day moving average, which has been curving lower.Google's chart has no recognizable pattern, although it has been able to mainly hold itself above the most recent buy point at 713.43. Persistent weakness at the 50-day line, however, would be a bad sign.Ebix (EBIX) broke out of a cup-without-handle base, jumping past the 38.39 buy point in heavy volume. The provider of software and e-commerce services to insurers has been rallying since Monday, when it beat profit expectations with a 44% jump in earnings per share.On the downside, Motorola Solutions (MSI) gapped lower to a loss of more than 4% in huge volume. There was no news to explain the sell-off. The stock broke out Thursday but has retraced its move and fallen as much as 5% below the 73.07 buy point.Image provided by Shutterstock.

The major stock indexes were higher in early afternoon trading Thursday, trading at session highs thanks to a midday burst.The Nasdaq was up 0.4% while the S&P 500 added 0.7% and the Dow Jones industrial average 0.8%. The S&P 500 has come to a new test of its 50-day moving average, which is trending downward. A move above the line would give chart readers some assurances about the current uptrend.Small-caps have been performing well this week, and the Russell 2000 showed an 0.8% advance.Volume was tracking sharply lower. Winning stocks led losers by a more than 2-to-1 ratio on the NYSE and by 9-to-7 on the Nasdaq.A few high-rated stocks cleared buy points in today's market session.Motorola Solutions (MSI) broke out of a choppy pattern, leaping past the 73.07 buy point in heavy trading. The communications equipment maker has been on a tear since it reported earnings late Monday that beat expectations. Sales lagged estimates, but the company's full-year outlook topped the consensus analyst estimate.Sturm Ruger (RGR) broke out of a cup-with-handle base in heavy trading, jumping past a 66.96 buy point. The firearms manufacturer beat profit expectations late Wednesday, with earnings excluding special items of 88 cents a share. Sales increased 24% to $152.4 million.Utilities remain in favor. American Electric Power (AEP) climbed above the 63.73 buy point of a long cup-with-handle base. But volume was tracking at less than half the normal pace, which suggests that few institutional investors were involved in the breakout.Becton Dickinson (BDX) is trying to break out of a double-bottom base. Shares edged above the 149.29 buy point. Volume also was lackluster, running about one-third smaller than normal for the medical supplies company.

Stock opened to modest losses Tuesday, as global markets took a breather after a strong start to the week.The Nasdaq and S&P 500 each started down 0.3%. The Dow opened to a 0.2% slip.Global markets sagged Tuesday as commodities prices backed way from gains and Britain's pound rebounded from a seven-year low -- both of which helped trip rallies from Shanghai to New York on Monday.BHP Billiton (BHP), one of the leaders of the FTSE 100's rally in London Monday, reported heavier-than-expected Q4 losses and slashed its dividend.  Regulators in China also added pressure, lowering the yuan's peg vs. the dollar.Leading benchmarks in China and Japan closed lower, but held to losses of less than 1%. In Europe, benchmark indexes traded down in the 0.5% range near midday.Oil slipped 2% early in Europe's trading session, then flattened by mid-morning. West Texas Intermediate spiked 6%, to near $32 a barrel, just before 9 a.m.. Saudi Arabia oil minister Ali Al-Naimi was scheduled to speak to oil executives this morning at an oil conference in Houston.Economic news likely to affect the U.S. stock market today includes Case-Shiller's 20-City Composite Home Price Index for December, due out at 9 a.m. ET. At 10 a.m., the Conference Board releases its February consumer confidence data and  the National Association of Realtors reports January existing home sales numbers.More than two-thirds of Dow stocks were in the red in premarket trade. But Home Depot (HD) lumbered ahead 4% after reporting a 17% gain in Q4 earnings, and a 9% revenue gain, both ahead of expectations.Management also boosted its full-year revenue guidance above consensus forecasts. Home Depot shares have been correcting since December, and caught below resistance at its 10-week moving average since early February.UnitedHealth Group (UNH) was the Dow's weakest stock, down 1% before the open. The managed care provider jumped 3% in rising volume on Monday.Western Digital (WDC) dropped 9% after announcing China-based Unisplendour had backed out of a $3.78 billion investment in the company.The change sends the $19 billion effort to merge with data storage peer Sandisk (SNDK) to plan B, which decreases the transaction's cash, raises the stock-per-share equation, and requires Western shareholders to approve the combination. SanDisk shares dropped 5% in premarket trade.Motorola (MSI) and Macy's (M) sparked up 6% each after healthy Q4 reports.In the IBD 50 stables, the few stocks posting premarket gains held to moves of less than 0.5%.Losses were also mild, led by Michael Kors (KORS), which slipped almost 2%, and Ryanair Holdings (RYAAY), with a 1% decline.Kors rose 4% in above-average trade Monday to 57% above a late January low, in an advance that is being cradled by the stock's 10-day moving average. Shares ended the session still 46% below a February 2014 high.Ryanair dropped 2% in heavy trade Monday. That put shares back below their 50-day moving average, which could present the stock with resistance. But the chart shows a possible cup-base forming, and the stock is in the proper range to add a handle to that cup.Image provided by Shutterstock.

Every Chicago police officer that responds to service calls will be equipped with a Taser (TASR) weapon by late spring, in Mayor Rahm Emanuel's latest move as part of an overhaul of the Chicago Police Department's lethal force policy. The number of officers with a Taser will double to 1,400. The changes are being made in the wake of last…
Stun gun and wearable camera systems maker Taser International (TASR) continued to rack up orders for its Axon body cameras last quarter, driving its stock up sharply Thursday.

The Scottsdale, Ariz.-based company announced orders for 1,018 Axon body cameras and Flex cameras in the current quarter so far. The company routinely doesn't disclose the value of contracts, but it said all of the orders will be shipped in the first quarter of 2016.

The biggest domestic order came from the Bryan Police Department in Bryan, Texas, which ordered 143 Axon Body 2 cameras with five years of Evidence.com service and warranties. According to a local TV station's news website, the cameras will cost $872,590 over the next five years. Denver International Airport ordered 132 Axon Flex cameras, and the Charlottesville, Va., police ordered 100 Axon Body and Flex cameras with five-year Evidence.com contracts.

Taser is expanding globally, and on Nov. 24 it announced it had received a long-term order for 22,000 body cameras from the London Metropolitan Police, its largest order ever. Details of the contract were still being worked out at the time, Taser said, and it plans to release the details in its February earnings call.
Taser stock closed up 6.6% at 17.73 in Thursday trading on the stock market today. It rose to an all-time high close at 35.03 on June 11 and has fallen about 50% since then.

Taser is still by far the market leader, but it's seen a rising tide of competition in the past year. Rivals now include Digital Ally (DGLY), Motorola Solutions (MSI), GoPro (GPRO), Japan's Panasonic and privately held fleet-vehicle and wearable camera maker Safety Vision.

Digital Ally shares jumped 15% Thursday after it announced that the U.S. Patent and Trademark office rejected a challenge by Taser to a key patent covering a system that automatically activates and records an event.
GoPro shot up 11.5% after it announced the name of its new camera-equipped drone slated to launch in early 2016, Karma. Motorola Solutions edged up fractionally.

Wearable camera makers have seen orders mount as police departments seek to document field situations in the wake of a series of officer shootings of unarmed suspects, including the shooting of 17-year-old Laquan McDonald in October 2014 in Chicago. McDonald was reportedly shot 16 times. Recently released video of the shooting has sparked demonstrations.

Chicago will expand its officer-worn camera pilot program, equipping another 1,400 officers in six more districts with the the devices. The city launched a pilot program in January, using Taser International's (TASR) Axon brand cameras and accompanying data storage and management systems. The expansion, announced on Sunday by Mayor Rahm Emanuel and Police Superintendent Garry McCarthy, is expected to be completed by mid-2016."Expanding this successful program into one-third of the city will help enhance transparency and credibility," Emanuel said in a press statement.The expansion comes in the wake of the public release of video showing a Chicago police officer fatally shooting 17-year-old Laquan McDonald. On Monday, Judge Donald Panarese set bail at $1.5 million for officer Jason Van Dyke, who has been charged with first-degree murder after allegedly shooting McDonald 16 times.Last Tuesday, the city released in-vehicle dash camera footage showing Van Dyke, who is white, shooting McDonald, who is black. Protesters marched in Chicago streets for several days after the video release and announcement of charges.Taser competes with a growing number of rivals in the body-worn camera market, including Digital Ally (DGLY), Motorola Solutions (MSI), GoPro (GPRO) and Japan's Panasonic in the officer-worn camera market. Ambarella (AMBA), which makes chips for GoPro action cams, also serves the law enforcement camera market.An increasing number of police agencies have adopted them amid rising numbers of protests over officer shootings of unarmed suspects. The Los Angeles Police Department is deploying Taser Axon cameras throughout its force, and London's police force picked Taser last week to provide body cameras.Since Chicago began its roll-out in January, more than 4,600 videos have been captured totaling more than 745 hours. Officers are currently evaluating the cameras for routine calls for service, investigatory stops, traffic stops, emergency vehicle response and evidence collection. So far, preliminary usage and operability results "are promising," city officials said.Taser ended trading down 0.7% on the stock market today. Its stock hit a 2015 high close at 35.03 on June 11. It's fallen about 47% since then and was trading below both its 50-day and 200-day averages.Digital Ally jumped 7.3%, Motorola Solutions dipped 0.3%, GoPro edged up 0.6% and Ambarella leapt 7.4%.Follow James DeTar on [email protected]_JDeTarand Facebook.

Taser International (TASR) won a contract Tuesday with the London metro police to equip 22,000 officers with its Axon body-worn cameras. The maker of its namesake stun guns and the Axon body camera systems says that the London Metropolitan Police Service is also purchasing Taser's digital evidence management tools. The tools let law enforcement agencies collect, store and manipulate data.The Police Service will deploy all of the cameras to frontline officers. Taser and the Police Service were still working out the contract's financial details, but Taser says that the order followed a 12-month pilot earlier this year using 1,000 Axon cameras. It was the largest trial of the devices to date and resulted in a 33% reduction in complaints against officers.Taser initially had the market virtually to itself, but it now competes with Digital Ally (DGLY), Motorola Solutions (MSI), GoPro (GPRO) and Japan's Panasonic in the officer-worn camera market. Ambarella (AMBA), which makes chips for GoPro action cams, also serves the law enforcement camera market.Still, "our Axon platform is now the most widely used body camera and digital evidence management solution in law enforcement," Taser CEO Patrick Smith said in a press statement.Metropolitan Police Commissioner Bernard Hogan-Howe said, "For too long, our equipment has lagged behind the technology almost everyone has in their pockets to capture events as they unfold."Taser says that more details could be forthcoming on its fourth quarter and full-year earnings call in February.Taser has struggled amid the intensified competition in body cameras and cyclical sales of its Taser weapons. Taser stun gun sales often rise in the wake of mass shootings or police shootings of civilians, and fall as time passes. Taser stock closed up 5.9% at 19.31 in Tuesday trading on the stock market today. It hit an all time-high at 35.95 on June 11; since then, it's fallen about 46%, including Tuesday's spike.Digital Ally rose 10.8%, and Motorola Solutions fell 0.4%. GoPro rose 1.7%. Ambarella advanced 2.7%.Follow James DeTar on [email protected]_JDeTar and Facebook.

The mishmash wins! Core stocks, which have neither predominantly growth nor value traits, have led both growth and value stocks in the past 10 years. Taking a shorter-term look, core stocks are running a distant second to growth stocks since June and year to date.Top-performing blend mutual funds of the past 10 years have outperformed the S&P 500 through Nov. 3. Blend mutual funds invest in growth and value stocks and/or core stocks.Blend funds can be a rich source of dividend-paying stocks.Parnassus Core Equity Fund has returned an average annual 10.50% the past 10 years vs. 7.89% for the S&P 500. The $12.3 billion fund is up 2.93% this year vs. 4.21% for the S&P 500, a proxy for the broad stock market.The fund has been managed by Todd Ahlsten since 2001 and Benjamin Allen since 2012.The fund seeks capital appreciation along with current income by owning stocks with a strong competitive advantage that protects market share and profitability. It favors quality management that acts in the best interest of shareholders. It looks for picks to have a favorable three-year investment horizon. It has a dividend yield of 1.21%.Recent holdings include Motorola Solutions (MSI), Danaher (DHR), Intel (INTC), Procter & Gamble (PG) and Gilead Sciences (GILD)Motorola Solutions' stock had been chugging along nicely until Wednesday when it fell 8% after reporting Q3 earnings. It's now 8% below is 52-week high and below its 50-day moving average.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters see earnings of the maker of wireless devices rising 29% this year and 16% next year. The stock has a dividend yield of 1.9%.Danaher, which makes test and treatment gear for science and environmental application, has seen modest but steady earnings growth the past three years. Net has risen at an 11% pace the past three years. Analysts see a 9% gain this year and 16% next year.The stock has crept higher this year after resting at its low several times.Intel's earnings are expected to decline 3% this year and rise 5% next year. The chipmaker's stock is now yielding 2.8%.Procter & Gamble's stock is 17% below its 52-week high and yielding 3.4%. The maker of household products has been increasing dividends at an annual 7% rate.Procter & Gamble's earnings are expected to fall 5% in the current fiscal year ending in June, but rise 13% the following year.Gilead Sciences' stock, once a highflier, has been struggling to make headway the past year. Earnings of the biotech company have risen at a 106% annual clip the past three years. They're seen rising 51% this year but falling 2% next year. The stock has a dividend yield of 1.6%.Parnassus Core Equity has 23% of its assets in industrial stocks, 20% in the tech sector and 16% in consumer defensive stocks.The fund has had a rich hunting ground the past 10 years. A $10,000 investment in the average core stock would have grown to $23,741 in that period, according to Morningstar Inc. data. The same investment would have grown to $23,416 in growth stocks, $18,217 in value stocks and $21,240 in the S&P 500.This year the average core stock is up 1% vs. 9.4% for growth stocks and 0.6% for value stocks.Follow Doug Rogers on Twitter @IBD_DRogers.
