The consolidation trend buzzing around the semiconductor industry is expected to continue into 2016, with SanDisk and Maxim Integrated Products the latest companies rumored to be on the sales block.
Speculation about the pair of takeover candidates surfaced just this week, after a record pace of consolidation this year.
In the first half of 2015, chip M&A action reached a $72.6 billion combined value — an all-time high and nearly six times the annual average the previous five years, according IC Insights.
Chipmakers are scrambling to remain profitable as organic growth slows amid a limp global economy, MKM Partners analyst Ian Ing told IBD.
"It's hard to latch onto secular growth," he said. "Even smartphones and the Internet of Things markets are slowing. The industry is maturing."
M&A buzz accelerated this week with reports that SanDisk (SNDK) might be acquired by Micron (MU) or Western Digital (WDC), and that Analog Devices (ADI) might be courting Maxim (MXIM).
Also, Fairchild Semiconductor (FCS) soared 16% Wednesday and another 3.1% Thursday on rumors it could be acquired.
They'd join a long list of deals.
In June, Intel (INTC) agreed to buy Altera (ALTR) for $16.7 billion.

In May, Apple (AAPL) iPhone chip supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO) announced an agreement to acquire Broadcom (BRCM) for $37 billion — then the biggest merger of pure-tech companies. This week's $67 billion merger agreement announced by Dell and EMC (EMC) is now No. 1.

This year, China's Tsinghua Group reportedly was interested in buying Micron for $23 billion as China tries to become less dependent on chip imports. Tsinghua recently invested $3.8 billion in Western Digital.

In the 1980s and 1990s, only "IBM (IBM) and Motorola (MSI) were highly integrated," Ing said. "Fast-forward to today, and there are really only 20 customers that matter (for chipmakers), so it makes sense to vertically integrate and scale."

Rather than a fractured and specialized industry, chipmakers will join forces to better appeal to heavyweight chip users such as Apple, Samsung Electronics (SSNLF), Hewlett-Packard (HP) and Cisco Systems (CSCO), he says.
Fabless firms, which don't do their own chip manufacturing, are most susceptible to M&A activity, he said.
"The fabless model is broken because specialization is down in software now vs. hardware," he said. "It makes sense to in-source your manufacturing."

Skyworks Solutions' (SWKS) $2 billion acquisition of PMC-Sierra (PMCS), announced this month, makes sense, Ing says. Skyworks sells chips to Apple for use in its iPhones, while PMC reaps revenue from Cisco, HP and Dell on the equipment side.
By combining, the two firms have stretched their portfolios, Ing says, and count at least four big hitters among customers.
Layoffs Certain

Summit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan says chipmakers must diversify as sales growth slows. "One company might have Samsung as a customer, and one company might have Apple as a customer, so by joining forces, no matter who wins, (the chipmakers) win," Sundararajan told IBD.

Some employees, though, will lose their jobs in these big mergers, he says. Avago and Broadcom estimate $750 million in cost synergy savings. Given a hypothetical $200,000 per employee (accounting for salary and benefits), that means 3,750 layoffs could occur.
Which companies are on the hunt?
Ing sees Intel, Texas Instruments (TXN), Analog Devices, Qualcomm (QCOM) and Avago as among the likeliest suitors.

"Look at Avago; they buy a big company like Broadcom, and after some period of time they're acquisitive again," he said. "Companies are going to do these deals, take a breather, reduce the waste they took on, de-lever their debts and then go shopping again."The consolidation trend buzzing around the semiconductor industry is expected to continue into 2016, with SanDisk and Maxim Integrated Products the latest companies rumored to be on the sales block.Speculation about the pair of takeover candidates surfaced just this week, after a record pace of consolidation this year.In the first half of 2015, chip M&A action reached a $72.6 billion combined value — an all-time high and nearly six times the annual average the previous five years, according IC Insights.Chipmakers are scrambling to remain profitable as organic growth slows amid a limp global economy, MKM Partners analyst Ian Ing told IBD."It's hard to latch onto secular growth," he said. "Even smartphones and the Internet of Things markets are slowing. The industry is maturing."M&A buzz accelerated this week with reports that SanDisk (SNDK) might be acquired by Micron (MU) or Western Digital (WDC), and that Analog Devices (ADI) might be courting Maxim (MXIM).Also, Fairchild Semiconductor (FCS) soared 16% Wednesday and another 3.1% Thursday on rumors it could be acquired.They'd join a long list of deals.In June, Intel (INTC) agreed to buy Altera (ALTR) for $16.7 billion.In May, Apple (AAPL) iPhone chip supplier Avago Technologies (AVGO) announced an agreement to acquire Broadcom (BRCM) for $37 billion — then the biggest merger of pure-tech companies. This week's $67 billion merger agreement announced by Dell and EMC (EMC) is now No. 1.This year, China's Tsinghua Group reportedly was interested in buying Micron for $23 billion as China tries to become less dependent on chip imports. Tsinghua recently invested $3.8 billion in Western Digital.In the 1980s and 1990s, only "IBM (IBM) and Motorola (MSI) were highly integrated," Ing said. "Fast-forward to today, and there are really only 20 customers that matter (for chipmakers), so it makes sense to vertically integrate and scale."Rather than a fractured and specialized industry, chipmakers will join forces to better appeal to heavyweight chip users such as Apple, Samsung Electronics (SSNLF), Hewlett-Packard (HP) and Cisco Systems (CSCO), he says.Fabless firms, which don't do their own chip manufacturing, are most susceptible to M&A activity, he said."The fabless model is broken because specialization is down in software now vs. hardware," he said. "It makes sense to in-source your manufacturing."Skyworks Solutions' (SWKS) $2 billion acquisition of PMC-Sierra (PMCS), announced this month, makes sense, Ing says. Skyworks sells chips to Apple for use in its iPhones, while PMC reaps revenue from Cisco, HP and Dell on the equipment side.By combining, the two firms have stretched their portfolios, Ing says, and count at least four big hitters among customers.Layoffs CertainSummit Research analyst Srini Sundararajan says chipmakers must diversify as sales growth slows. "One company might have Samsung as a customer, and one company might have Apple as a customer, so by joining forces, no matter who wins, (the chipmakers) win," Sundararajan told IBD.Some employees, though, will lose their jobs in these big mergers, he says. Avago and Broadcom estimate $750 million in cost synergy savings. Given a hypothetical $200,000 per employee (accounting for salary and benefits), that means 3,750 layoffs could occur.Which companies are on the hunt?Ing sees Intel, Texas Instruments (TXN), Analog Devices, Qualcomm (QCOM) and Avago as among the likeliest suitors."Look at Avago; they buy a big company like Broadcom, and after some period of time they're acquisitive again," he said. "Companies are going to do these deals, take a breather, reduce the waste they took on, de-lever their debts and then go shopping again."

Stocks survived more volatility to end with gains Monday, but biotechs sold off. The Nasdaq ended up a fraction after falling about 0.6% intraday. But the tech-laden index was up as much as 1.1% about an hour into the session. Biotechs, which include some market-leading stocks, got whacked as presidential candidate Hillary Clinton took to Twitter to criticize drug prices.…
Baker Hughes (BHI) is getting attention from ValueAct Capital Management as the oilfield service provider waits for approval for its merger with Halliburton (HAL).

ValueAct, an activist fund, said in a regulatory filing that Baker Hughes is undervalued, according to the Wall Street Journal, and could look to add a ValueAct representative to Baker Hughes' board to help boost shareholder value.
Baker Hughes shares closed up 1.2% to 55.31 in the stock market today. Halliburton shares jumped 3.5% to 39.04. Rival Schlumberger (SLB) gained 2.6%.

ValueAct has a 5.3% stake in Baker Hughes and is normally quiet about its interactions with companies it has large stakes in, rather than making demands public. It also owns large stakes in Adobe Systems (ADBE) and Motorola Solutions (MSI).
Baker Hughes and Halliburton announced their merger in November 2014 but may face trouble getting antitrust approval for the deal.

The Justice Department is reportedly complicating the Halliburton-Baker Hughes merger by requiring Halliburton to sell the $7.5 billion in assets it needs to offload to pass antitrust regulations to a single buyer, according to the New York Post.
Possible asset buyers include General Electric (GE) or Siemens (SIEGY). General Electric shares closed up 1.75% to 27.29.

Stocks picked up steam in late trading Tuesday, hitting fresh session highs. Hopes of more stimulus out of China were lifting U.S. stocks. The Nasdaq led with a 2.3% gain, while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average rallied 2.1% each. Turnover was running higher compared with the same time Friday on both major exchanges.

Fitbit (FIT) was off its session high, but still up 8% after Morgan Stanley upgraded the stock to overweight from equal weight and upped its price target to 58 from 43. Shares were up nearly 13% intraday. Fitbit, which came public in June, has fallen 41% since hitting a record high Aug. 5.

Synnex (SNX) jumped 5% in active trading and cleared an 80.32 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The stock has now recovered from a 9% dive from June 26, which was in reaction to a drop in Q2 sales and a weak outlook.

Motorola Solutions (MSI) rose 2% to a six-month high in fast trade. It cleared a 67.27 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. The company recently launched a new collection of its Moto 360 smartwatches.

On the downside, Netflix (NFLX) slumped 4% after reversing lower earlier in the stock market today. The stock is on pace for a seventh straight loss and at risk of finishing below its closing price in the wild session on Aug. 24. Netflix was among a few leaders being sold by insiders recently.
Casey's General Stores (CASY), Dave & Buster's Entertainment (PLAY), HealthEquity (HQY), Korn/Ferry (KFY) and Men's Wearhouse (MW) are a few notable firms reporting earnings after the close.

Stocks again opened to narrow losses on Friday, with retail sector stocks experiencing unusually heavy selling. The Nasdaq hurt worst, down 0.9%. The Dow Jones industrial average carved out a 0.7% decline and the S&P 500 fell 0.5%.
Trade was mixed, up 13% on the Nasdaq and 5% lower on the NYSE, compared with action at the same time Thursday
The stock market today felt some early drag from company reports compounded by a raft of weaker-than-forecast producer price and retail sales data.
Business inventories expanded 0.3%, the Commerce Department said, vs. consensus views for no change.

Consumer sentiment offered a bright spot, with the University of Michigan's November Consumer Sentiment Index jumping to 93.1, up from 90 in September and above views for an improvement to 92. It was the index's best reading since July.
In stocks, a number of heavy premarket moves held through to the regular session:

Generic-drug maker Mylan (MYL) surged 8% and Perrigo (PRGO) slumped 8% after Mylan failed in its attempted hostile $26 billion takeover of Michigan-based Perrigo. The Wall Street Journal reported Mylan's cash-for-stock tender offer garnered only 40% of Perrigo shares. Mylan needed at least 50% for a successful takeover. The offer expired at 8 a.m. Friday.

Switzerland-based seed strain and herbicide giant Syngenta (SYT) leapt 7% after a Bloomberg report that the company rejected a $42 billion takeover offer from state-owned China National Chemical Corp. Syngenta refused a $47 billion offer from Monsanto (MON) earlier this year.

Retail groups showed nine of the market's 10 worst losses among industries in the first half hour of trade. Fossil Group (FOSL) collapsed 30%, Nordstrom (JWN) crumbled 18% after reporting weak quarterly results late Thursday.
Video game retailer GameStop (GME) dropped 12%. Grilled chicken chain El Pollo Loco (LOCO) unraveled 13%.

Chip equipment maker Applied Materials (AMAT) climbed 4%. The Santa Clara, Cal. outfit reported in line fiscal Q4 results after Thursday's close. But management said during the quarterly conference call that the company could be open to the possibility of a merger. Applied Materials has been climbing off a September low, but remains deep in an eight-month consolidation.
Leading stocks opened the session in a lousy mood, with more than four in every five stocks on the IBD 50 list losing ground in early action.

China-based TAL Education (XRS) posted the best move in the group, up almost 2% to peck out another new high. The provider of kindergarten through 12th grade after school tutoring services is now nearly 8% past a 38.75 buy point in a cup with handle base.

At the low end of the list, Paycom Software (PAYC) lopped off 7%. The Oklahoma City-based provider of online human-capital management programs priced a 4.5 million share offering at 42.50, a 5% discount to Thursday's closing price. The loss dragged shares back below a 41.68 buy point, but left the stock above its 50-day line of support.

Stocks rose sharply Tuesday, triggering a bullish signal for the market. The Nasdaq surged 2.7% and the S&P 500 2.5%. Even for the volatile market lately, those were sizable jumps. Volume rose. The combination of big price gains and higher volume resulted in a follow-through signal — a confirmation of the rally that began with the dramatic Aug. 24 index…

Investors stampeded out of Zebra Technologies stock on Tuesday after the maker of asset-tracking technology missed Wall Street's fiscal second-quarter earnings target and guided lower for Q3 earnings.

Zebra (ZBRA) stock plunged to a seven-month low of 81.01 and ended the day at 83.80, down 24% . Shares hit an all-time high of 119.47 on June 23 and at that point had doubled in the prior eight months.

Zebra early Tuesday said that it had earned $1.05 a share excluding items, up 14% year over year, on sales of $890 million, up 209%, in the quarter ended July 4. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expected Zebra to earn $1.18 a share ex items on sales of $885 million.
The big jump in sales was the result of Zebra acquiring the enterprise business of Motorola Solutions (MSI) last October.
The Lincolnshire, Ill.-based Zebra's gross profit margin dipped to 44.2% in Q2 from 49.3% a year earlier.
On a GAAP basis, Zebra lost $76.3 million, or $1.50 a share, in the quarter. GAAP includes costs associated with Zebra's $3.45 billion acquisition of Motorola's enterprise business.

For the third quarter, Zebra expects to earn $1.23 a share excluding items on sales of $915 million, based on the midpoint of guidance. Analysts were modeling for Zebra to earn $1.41 a share on sales of $916 million.
Forecasts Margin Uptick
Zebra is targeting a Q3 gross profit margin of 44.8% to 45.8%, CFO Michael Smiley said on a conference call with analysts.

Zebra makes systems for tracking inventory and assets using bar-code scanners and radio frequency identification (RFID) tags. It has offerings for health care, manufacturing, retail, hospitality and transportation and logistics industries.

Zebra's pursuit of large contracts for mobile computing devices, which carry lower profit margins for the company, impacted its bottom line. These deals are important for Zebra because they are expected to lead to follow-on sales of higher-margin products and services, Zebra CEO Anders Gustafsson told IBD.
Honeywell (HON) is a principal competitor in the mobile computing deals.

"Our customers are thinking of us much more as a strategic partner" since the Motorola acquisition, Gustafsson said. Zebra is much better positioned now to cross-sell products and services to corporate customers, he says.
Customers are upgrading the handheld scanners and other mobile devices that they use to track assets, because Microsoft (MSFT) is transitioning from Windows CE to Windows 10.
This operating system migration has created an opening for Google's (GOOGL) Android to gain ground in the market.
Zebra is agnostic and will sell both Windows 10 and Android-based devices, Gustafsson said.

This "once-in-a-decade transition" is providing Zebra a great opportunity to gain market share, he said. "We are trying to aggressively go after and win all these new large installations to gain a foothold. Our history has shown that once we get into an account and start delivering product, we can start working on cost reductions, cross-selling other things, and the margin profile gets to be much more attractive."
In June, Zebra won a contract from U.K. postal service Royal Mail for 76,000 handheld scanners.
The mobile device operating system migration will largely be finished by 2018 or so, he said.
Zebra is focused on building its business for the long term. The stock market response Tuesday to Zebra's earnings report is a "knee-jerk reaction" to short-term trends, Gustafsson said.
Focus On Share Gains
Northcoast Research analyst Keith Housum called the earnings report "very disappointing."

Zebra should have done a better job of telegraphing that its pursuit of large hardware deals, especially in the lower-margin retail and field services markets, would pressure the company's gross margins, Housum told IBD.
"The long-term story is still intact," Housum said. "Their big focus is on making sure that they gain market share and they're going to be going to bat against consumer devices in some cases."
Great Lakes Review analyst Elliott Schlang also said the Q2 results and guidance from Zebra were a disappointment, but he said he remains upbeat about the company's prospects.
Schlang rates Zebra stock as "gradual accumulate."
"Fundamentally we continue to feel very good about (Zebra)," he told IBD. But he reduced his expectations for Zebra's earnings in the near term.
Zebra has room for improvement in profitability as it continues to wring out cost savings from its combination with the Motorola business.

"These integrations don't happen overnight," Schlang said. "They continue to make headway ... . Now if they can get their costs under control and get the big orders continuing to come in, they'll have the best of both worlds."
Zebra is positioned at the nexus of three hot trends: mobile computing, the Internet cloud and the Internet of Things. Zebra offers customers what it calls "enterprise asset intelligence."

Zebra offers customers what it calls "enterprise asset intelligence."
The biggest acquisition in its history has already paid dividends for Zebra Technologies, which topped consensus earnings views for both quarters since the deal closed.
The company looks to continue that streak next week when it reports second-quarter results.

Zebra (ZBRA) makes and sells direct thermal and thermal-transfer label printers, radio frequency identification (RFID) printer/encoders, dye sublimation card printers and an array of related accessories, solutions and software.

Zebra products have a variety of uses, from printing bar-code labels, receipts and plastic ID cards to encoding passive RFID smart labels and cards. Its asset-tracking technologies incorporate bar codes and RFID as well as mobile computing, data capture, wireless local area networks, location systems and Zatar, the company's cloud-based Internet of Things (IoT) platform.
End markets include health care, retail, manufacturing, transportation and logistics, hospitality and warehouse management.
Zebra is part of IBD's Computer-Hardware/Peripherals group, which also includes tech heavyweights Apple (AAPL), Hewlett-Packard (HPQ) and Canon (CAJ).
Calling On Motorola
After logging only single-digit EPS and revenue growth in 2012 and 2013, Zebra last year delivered a 61% revenue gain and a 27% earnings increase.
The company got a lift from rising demand for its core thermal bar-code and RFID printers as well as its October 2014 acquisition of Motorola Solutions' (MSI) Enterprise Solutions (ES) business.
That deal, valued at $3.45 billion and funded with about $200 million in cash and $3.25 billion in new debt, is forecast to boost growth even higher this year.

"The acquisition is really transforming the company to be a source of all equipment rather than their traditional, narrower niche. It's one-stop shopping for customers," said Elliott Schlang, managing director of Great Lakes Review, an institutional research boutique in Cleveland.

The Motorola business deepened Zebra's portfolio of bar-code scanning and RFID technologies, including those that let warehouse managers track inventory with handheld devices or help medical personnel store information on patients. In addition, the acquired unit brought aboard expertise in mobile platforms and other advanced technologies geared toward the Internet of Things.
The $3.45 billion price tag was pretty hefty for a company that logged under $1.7 billion in revenue last year, but so far the integration seems to be going well, analysts say.

"There's a risk whenever a company of this size makes a major acquisition and pays through the nose for it," Schlang told IBD. "But thus far, the speedy integration and the very meaningful strategic acquisition they made gives us some comfort that (the deal) will continue to do well for them."

Zebra has fully integrated the Motorola unit's sales staff, says Northcoast Research analyst Keith Housum, but the back office integration will take longer. "All indications are that the integration is coming along well," he told IBD.
Synergies At Scale

The deal certainly made sense from a logistics standpoint, Housum says. Both Zebra and the Motorola ES unit did business through many of the same channels and with many of the same distributors. The combined company has been able to take advantage of more efficiencies and scale.

That scale is reflected in Zebra's recent financial performance. It has delivered two straight quarters of triple-digit revenue growth since the deal closed and is expected to do the same when it reports second-quarter earnings on Aug. 11.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Zebra to post Q2 revenue of $885.4 million, up from $288.4 million the prior year. EPS is seen rising 40% to $1.18.
The company reported Q1 earnings of $1.39 a share, well above consensus estimates of $1.12. Revenue more than tripled to $893.2 million, also above views.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect full-year earnings to rise 52% this year and 24% in 2016.
"The enterprise side is going through a growth cycle that I expect will continue through the next two years, which will help drive results," Housum said.
Along with that growth should come an improvement in the acquired Motorola ES unit's performance, he says.
"The enterprise segment had issues with management as well as issues in Asia," Housum said, but changes in the unit's management late last year have helped resolve many of those issues.
In an email to IBD, Zebra spokeswoman Therese Van Ryne said that the integration of the Motorola Solutions Enterprise business into Zebra is "going well."

"We're focused on being flexible, making good decisions and hitting key target dates," she added. "The continued hard work, collaboration and commitment of Zebra employees is driving our success. These efforts are making Zebra an even more innovative and customer-focused company."

Meanwhile, Zebra's core printer and RFID businesses also continue to produce strong results, Schlang says. "They continue to do three to four times what their nearest competitor does in their basic core business: the thermal bar-code printer. That has perked up in both the retail and industrial sectors."

Zebra has an IBD Composite Rating of 95, placing it atop IBD's Computer-Hardware/Peripherals industry group. "All indications are that the integration is coming along well," he told IBD.Synergies At ScaleThe deal certainly made sense from a logistics standpoint, Housum says. Both Zebra and the Motorola ES unit did business through many of the same channels and with many of the same distributors. The combined company has been able to take advantage of more efficiencies and scale.That scale is reflected in Zebra's recent financial performance. It has delivered two straight quarters of triple-digit revenue growth since the deal closed and is expected to do the same when it reports second-quarter earnings on Aug. 11.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Zebra to post Q2 revenue of $885.4 million, up from $288.4 million the prior year. EPS is seen rising 40% to $1.18.The company reported Q1 earnings of $1.39 a share, well above consensus estimates of $1.12. Revenue more than tripled to $893.2 million, also above views.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect full-year earnings to rise 52% this year and 24% in 2016."The enterprise side is going through a growth cycle that I expect will continue through the next two years, which will help drive results," Housum said.Along with that growth should come an improvement in the acquired Motorola ES unit's performance, he says."The enterprise segment had issues with management as well as issues in Asia," Housum said, but changes in the unit's management late last year have helped resolve many of those issues.In an email to IBD, Zebra spokeswoman Therese Van Ryne said that the integration of the Motorola Solutions Enterprise business into Zebra is "going well.""We're focused on being flexible, making good decisions and hitting key target dates," she added. "The continued hard work, collaboration and commitment of Zebra employees is driving our success. These efforts are making Zebra an even more innovative and customer-focused company."Meanwhile, Zebra's core printer and RFID businesses also continue to produce strong results, Schlang says. "They continue to do three to four times what their nearest competitor does in their basic core business: the thermal bar-code printer. That has perked up in both the retail and industrial sectors."Zebra has an IBD Composite Rating of 95, placing it atop IBD's Computer-Hardware/Peripherals industry group. Zebra stock trades near 105, down from a high of 119.47 set on June 23.

Two top-rated IBD 50 tech stocks report second-quarter financial results Tuesday, cybersecurity company CyberArk Software (CYBR) and Zebra Technologies (ZBRA), whose suite of advanced technology helps companies track products.
CyberArk is a small but fast-growing Internet security company.

The Israel-based firm, which reports after the market closes Tuesday, focuses on providing security for privileged accounts — key executives and others with access to confidential data within an organization. Its software works inside a company's network to protect and defend against attacks.
Analyst consensus is for CyberArk to report Q2 earnings per share of 6 cents on $32.38 million in revenue. No comps are available for the September 2014 IPO.
In Q1, it reported 16 cents EPS, vs. views for 5 cents. In Q4 2014, its first full-quarter report, it had 21 cents EPS, trouncing Wall Street's 5-cent target.

CyberArk is part of a group of fast-growing companies fighting waves of cyberattacks. The blue chip group includes Palo Alto Networks (PANW), whose platform provides corporate security and whose stock boasts a best-possible 99 IBD Composite Rating. Israel's Check Point Software (CHKP) and China's Cheetah Mobile (CMCM) also are in the software security group.
(So is Symantec (SYMC), which also reports earnings Tuesday night. But earnings and revenue have been spotty and the stock has been in a downtrend. Symantec has a Composite Rating of just 53.)
CyberArk began trading on Sept. 24 after pricing at 16 in its initial public offering.

Its stock has risen 277% in nine months and closed above 60 Friday, up about 3% for the day in trading on the stock market. Shares have found resistance at the 50-day moving average since the end of June.
(By comparison, Palo Alto Networks fell nearly 6% for the week, closing below its 200-day moving average.)
Zebra Technologies makes and sells portable computers, thermal and thermal-transfer label printers, radio frequency identification (RFID) printers and encoders and other products.
Its products are used for everything from printing bar-code labels, receipts and plastic ID cards to encoding passive RFID smart labels and cards onto merchandise.
In October, Zebra completed its biggest-ever acquisition, buying Motorola Solutions' (MSI) Enterprise Solutions business for $3.45 billion.
Wall Street expects Zebra, whose stock is also on the prestigious IBD Leaderboard list, to report a 207% increase in revenue to $885.4 million Tuesday morning.

Zebra is also projected to record a 41% jump in EPS to $1.18. It topped earnings estimates the prior quarter, after missing in Q4 2014. Investors will look to see if the company can make it two in a row.

A zebra can't change its stripes, but Zebra Technologies does. The company has evolved from a maker of bar code printers and readers to a broad-based provider of technologies for tracking assets.

Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) sits at the nexus of three major trends in technology: mobility, cloud computing and the Internet of Things. It provides a host of hardware and software for tracking an organization's assets, people and transactions using bar codes and radio frequency identification (RFID) tags.
Zebra has specific offerings for the health care, manufacturing, retail, hospitality, and transportation and logistics industries.

On May 13, Zebra soundly beat Wall Street's estimates for its fiscal first quarter, thanks to a boost from its acquisition last October of Motorola Solutions' (MSI) enterprise business. Its stock surged to an all-time high on the news, above 111, and hit a new high on Wednesday above 115, but closed down 2 cents.
Lincolnshire, Ill.-based Zebra has posted seven straight quarters of double-digit earnings growth.

For the quarter ended April 4, Zebra earned $1.39 a share excluding items, up 53% from the year-earlier quarter, on sales of $893 million, up 210%. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected Zebra to earn $1.12 a share on sales of $882 million.
For the current quarter, Zebra expects non-GAAP earnings of $1.13 a share, up 35%, on sales of $880 million, up 205%, based on the midpoint of guidance.

"The solid Q1/Q2 guide gets Zebra largely past the high-risk integration quarters" after the Motorola acquisition, Wells Fargo Securities analyst Andrew Spinola said in a May 13 research report. The company is ahead of schedule on recognizing cost savings and synergies from the deal, he said. Spinola rates Zebra stock outperform.
Motorola Deal Sways Skeptics

Zebra's purchase of the Motorola Solutions' unit has proved to be transformative, Great Lakes Review analyst Elliott Schlang told IBD. When Zebra announced the $3.45 billion deal in April 2014, there were skeptics, he says.

"They decided to take a significant risk in what they paid for it and also in making their first major acquisition and taking on the debt that they did, given their historic pure balance sheet," Schlang said.

Zebra CFO Michael Smiley told IBD that the company is excited about the potential to offer its enterprise customers a deeper set of products for tracking assets. He says customers include 95% of the Fortune 500.
For companies with inventory, Zebra Technologies offers systems that help answer four basic questions:
 What's in the box?
 Where is the box?
 How are things in the box?
 How has that box moved?
"All that information allows you to manage what's important to you better," Smiley said.
He says the mobile computing, cloud computing and Internet of Things trends are compelling for the company.
"When you put those together, we're at the vortex," Smiley said. "By virtue of the combination, we become a much more strategic vendor to our customers."
Zebra has garnered attention for its deal with the National Football League.
Last year, Zebra installed a system for tracking NFL players and referees in real time at 17 stadiums. For the upcoming season, it is expanding the program to all stadiums in the league.

With the technology, teams can capture precise data, such as position, speed and distance, from RFID tags in players' shoulder pads. With the data, the NFL can track such statistics as player acceleration and total distance run.

The NFL deal provides a showcase to demonstrate Zebra's technologies to potential customers in many industries.A zebra can't change its stripes, but Zebra Technologies does. Stock opened the week quietly lower, as oil prices added to last week's gains and earnings reports levied only a modest impact on early trade.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 0.3% while the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq slipped 0.2% each.
The stock market today launched in weak trade, with volume down 27% on the Nasdaq and 19% lower on the NYSE vs. action at the same time Friday.

Airlines were under pressure as oil prices gained. The U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude gained 2% to near $53 a barrel. United Continental (UAL), Delta Air Lines (DAL) and American Airlines (AAL) all fell 4%.

Qualcomm (QCOM) defied expectations and jumped 4% after news reports in China said regulators might fine the company as much as $1.6 billion for antitrust violations. The company has been under investigation since November 2013, according to Bloomberg. The fine would be the largest by Chinese regulators against a foreign operator. Qualcomm shares have been in a deepening correction since July.

Communications device maker Motorola Solutions (MSI) leapt 5% in heavy trade to lead the S&P 500. The move followed a Wall street Journal report citing unnamed sources claiming the company was exploring a possible sale, with Honeywell International (HON) named as a possible buyer. Motorola has been trading flat, within a narrow range for 13 months.

On the IBD 50 list, IPG Photonics (IPGP) popped 3%, pressing further into new highs following its 10% breakout surge last week. The maker of fiber optic lasers and components is now 9% past a flat base buy point of 77.74.
At the low end of the list, Alaska Air (ALK) dropped 3%. The stock has pulled back sharply from January 29 high and is leaning toward a test of its 10-week moving average.

After the close, software security firm Qualys (QLYS), containerboard maker KapStone Paper & Packaging (KS) and China-based online gaming leader NetEase (NTES) are among the companies scheduled to report.

So is Molina Healthcare (MOH), which faces hefty sales and earnings expectations as it rebound from a weak December quarter a year ago. Late winter and early spring were challenging for $1.8 billion AllianceBernstein Discovery Growth , which focuses on small- and midcap growth stocks.
Large caps edged out small and midcaps. Value topped growth.
But now comes the fun part for Bruce Aronow, lead manager of this mutual fund.

He said, "When we've gone through similar (outperformance by large caps and value) in the stock market in the past, that created opportunities that enabled us to quickly recover. Six to 12 months out, we made up the underperformance and then some."
Smaller caps and growth outperformed in June. Aronow expects more of that going forward.
Part of that stems from midcaps like Zebra Technologies (ZBRA). A leader in bar-code printer manufacturing, shares are up 51% this year.

"These guys are the only game in town for RFID (radio-frequency ID) bar-code printers," Aronow said. Spending for their products slowed during and right after the financial crisis, Aronow says. "So there's good pent-up demand."
Also, Zebra has continued to innovate, driving replacement demand.

And Zebra is acquiring Motorola's (MSI) technology for reading bar codes via RFID chips. "That gives Zebra the ability to close the loop and sell to a new customer base as well as existing customers," Aronow said.
The fund started its current stake in the first quarter and boosted it in April and May.
Early In Cycle
Aronow likes the outlook for midcap construction-equipment renter United Rentals (URI).
"It's showing improvements in utilization and pricing," Aronow said. "And we're still early in the nonresidential construction recovery."

The company reported Q2 earnings per share of $1.65, up 47%, on July 16. "That was a 20-cent upside surprise, showing strong business momentum," Aronow said. Its stock hit an all-time high of 114.95 the next day. It's up 43% this year.
The firm came through the financial crisis well-financed, Aronow says, with a better fleet of equipment than its rivals. Those factors help to drive price and usage.
The fund has trimmed its stake in recent disclosures, taking profits and managing risk, Aronow says.
Midcap Akorn's (AKRX) EPS growth has accelerated for two quarters. Shares are up 38% this year.

The maker of specialty drugs focused on ophthalmologic injectables has a pipeline that could lead to billions of dollars in new sales, Aronow says. He also likes the prospect of additional acquisitions.

Aronow says that staffing firm Robert Half International (RHI), which Tuesday reported earnings and sales rose in Q2, is in good markets: finance, technology and accounting. Amid tightening demand in those markets, what Half charges customers rises faster than what Half pays its temps, Aronow says.
And Half's sales efforts enable the firm's market share to grow faster than the market, he adds.

Hampered earlier this year by large-cap and value outperformance, Aronow's fund was down 1.7% this year, going into Tuesday. Its midcap growth peers tracked by Morningstar averaged a 2.11% gain. The S&P 500 was up 7.97%.

Over the past three years, the fund's average annual gain is 12.35% vs. 11.67% for its direct rivals and 16.17% for the S&P 500.Late winter and early spring were challenging for $1.8 billion AllianceBernstein Discovery Growth , which focuses on small- and midcap growth stocks.Large caps edged out small and midcaps. Giving a novice pilot the controls of a Learjet is risky.The aircraft don't fly anything like the prop planes most noncommercial pilots train on.They climb steeper, bank harder and move faster.A lot faster.Shaky, inexperienced hands can lose control and send the plane back to Earth, sans runway.That possibility didn't trouble the owner — Bill Lear — when he gave investment banker Clint Allen, who had "just earned my multiengine aircraft rating," the controls of a Learjet 23 to fly most of the way on a two-hop flight from Boston to Reno, Nev."The 23 climbed like a fighter," Allen wrote of his experience. "I felt like we were heading for the Gulf of Tonkin."RelaxOnce they hit cruising altitude, Lear told Allen, "I'm going to take a little nap. Wake me if anything happens you can't handle."The man was kidding about the nap, but his joke pointed to a familiarity with and confidence in his jet that few could match; which only makes sense when you consider that he invented it — over many people's loud objections.Lear once bragged about his namesake jet, "They said I'd never build it; that if I built it, it wouldn't fly; that if it flew, I couldn't sell it. Well I did and it did and I could."Lear (1902-78) didn't let others' doubts keep him grounded.Allen, who writes about the business of aviation for Forbes, calls Oct. 7, 1963, a major turning point in flying history. That was the day the first Learjet "took to the Kansas skies, rocketed into the stratosphere to 41,000 (feet) in record time and achieved a staggering speed of 605 mph."Lear's new plane, wrote Allen, "dazzled the world and changed business aviation forever, bringing unheard-of levels of performance, utility, practicality and affordability to the skies across America."Yet aviation enthusiasts' focus on the Learjet, and Lear's later failed attempts to launch cutting-edge aircraft, overshadow a much larger legacy of innovation.Lear was a great American tinkerer and entrepreneur, with more than 150 patents and inventions to his name.He was inducted not only into the National Aviation Hall of Fame, but also the National Inventors Hall of Fame.Born in Hannibal, Mo., to parents whose marriage soon dissolved, the electrical bug bit Lear early in life. He was always disassembling machines to see how they worked, and improving them.Young At WarThings the young Lear built included a radio and a telegraph, and of course he learned Morse code. This skill set came in handy when President Wilson took America into World War I in 1917.Lear grew up fast by today's standards. He dropped out of school after eighth grade. Then at age 16 he fudged his age to join the Navy as a much-needed radio operator.After World War I ended in 1918, Lear bounced in and out of companies as an expert in all things radio.He improved radios in several ways that have been recognized by historians of the medium:• Lear's battery eliminator made it possible to power radios using standard electrical outlets.• He produced new speakers to pump up the volume.• He invented one of the first car radios, which eventually put a little firm called Motorola (MSI) on the map.He later invented the 8-track player, a byproduct of his twin obsessions of radio and flight.At The ControlsLear volunteered as a grease monkey at Chicago's Grant Park Airport, where he learned to fly.And once he got into a cockpit, he decided some improvements were in order.In the 1990s, Jeff Eicher bought and restored a 1934 Monocoupe plane with his father, Robert. They found out from an article in Mechanics Illustrated it was the same aircraft that Lear used to test out a prototype of his Lear-o-Matic autopilot system for light planes.In the 1930s, the Monocoupe belonged to Lear's friend Roy McGuire. McGuire let Lear use the plane as a guinea pig, and it worked well enough.According to the New York Times, Lear is known in the aviation industry "for having contributed more to the safety of flying than any other man of his era."Said Eicher, "Lear's autopilot was innovative for its small size and in that the gyro was tilted topside aft, allowing it to control the aircraft in both roll and yaw (angles of rotation). To my knowledge, this had never been done before."When Eicher stripped the aircraft down to the frame, he looked for signs where the servomechanism had been mounted. He didn't find anything, alas, but was still glad to own a piece of history.Lear's autopilot device was but one of his many inventions that improved flying on a large scale. The Encyclopedia Britannica reports, "By 1939 more than half the private airplanes in the United States were using Lear radio and navigational equipment."When World War II hit Asia and Europe in the 1930s, Lear Development (later Lear Inc.) in Santa Monica, Calif., was in a good position to help out and profit. It manufactured motors and navigation and precision devices for Allied forces.After the postwar sales boom, Lear decided to get into the airline manufacturing game in the 1950s. His business partners balked. They didn't think the company had the capital or expertise to pull it off.Lear summarized their dismissive attitude as telling him "to go play with a radio or something."So Lear did something many top founders or CEOs would consider unappealing. In 1962 he accepted a buyout of his stake in Lear Inc. and used that $14.3 million (worth $108 million today) as seed money to get his Learjet off the ground.Lear knew he could pull it off because the task wasn't so much engineering as backward engineering.He didn't have much formal education, but he was expert at pulling things apart, seeing how they work and putting them back together better than ever.His Learjet was based on the design of a Swiss fighter jet.Lear worked around the clock in Switzerland and Wichita, Kan., hovering over engineers at times, to take most of the speed and functionality of a jet and bottle it in a smaller, sleek, affordable package.His tinkering again paid off, remaking the commercial aviation industry in the process, when the Learjet took off in the fall of '63.Lear's soaring plane is still manufactured. In 1990 Learjet Corp. — the company formed with seed money from a Lear Inc. buyout — was bought by the Canadian firm Bombardier Aerospace, which now boasts the Learjet 85.Lear never put his stamp on one company the way many titans of American business have done. He was restless and relentless, which made him hard to work with and even harder to live with.He was married four times, fathering seven children.Bucking The TrendHis vices were also his virtues. Few people would sell their stake in a successful company that they had founded and built up to take an expensive chance on a type of plane that had, as yet, no mass market to sell to.Lear did so because he saw money, in part, as only a means to an end. That end was a certain kind of immortality."What motivates inventors?" asked Andrew Boyd of the University of Houston's Department of Industrial Engineering. "For many it's the sheer joy of inventing."Added Boyd: For a "small few," including Lear, the motivation is "an all-consuming, maniacal drive — a desire to change the world and be recognized for doing so."

Stocks mounted a comeback and have turned mixed in late trading Tuesday.

The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 were each up about 0.1%. They were off by as much as 0.7% and 0.8%, respectively. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq pared a 1.9% drop to 0.6% after finding support near its 200-day line. Turnover continued to track sharply higher across the board in the stock market today.

Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) tumbled 11% and sliced its 50-day line. It rumbled up 11% in premarket trade. The Illinois-based maker of barcode and scanning-related technologies was up as much as 5% after updating its Q1 earnings and revenue guidance to above consensus forecasts. The firm also said it had agreed to pay $3.45 billion to buy Motorola Solutions' (MSI) enterprise business. Zebra said the deal would immediately add to earnings, and that it planned to add 4,500 employees once the deal was closed.
Anika Therapeutics (ANIK) was off its session low, but still down nearly 7%. Anika is also on pace to close below support at its 50-day moving average.
Wynn Resorts (WYNN) dropped 4% to its lowest levels since late January. The stock has fallen for five weeks and counting and is now 20% off its March peak.

Leaders up in volume were few, but Michael Kors (KORS) rose 2%, putting it on track for a second straight gain. Earlier Tuesday, the fashion house announced that it signed a 10-year licensing deal with Italian eyewear-maker Luxottica Group (LUX).

When you enter Greg Brown's office, you cannot miss the glass wall. Filled with his scribbles, the floor-to-ceiling wall doubles as a whiteboard for Brown to jot ideas and reminders.
Chairman and CEO of Motorola Solutions (MSI), Brown uses the wall as a huge notepad. When managers visit, they can scan the wall to get a better understanding of what issues Brown is tracking.
"They see what I see," said Brown, 52. "They know what I know. They have a complete sense of my priorities" by looking at the wall.

Brown, a self-described visual thinker, has a non-negotiable rule that only he can write on his wall or erase something from it. But his lieutenants at the Schaumburg, Ill.-based maker of communications gear tell him when they've taken care of a pending item so that he can remove it.

"The wall has a couple hundred items on it — from tactical to strategic and from big to little," Brown said. "Everything from to-dos, meetings coming up, partners, people. It might remind me of the status of a deal or information on a competitor."
Speak Less, Speak Last
Brown's glass wall reflects his commitment to transparency. He wants colleagues to feel comfortable speaking up, and seeing what's on his mind tends to trigger better, fuller conversations.
Similarly, Brown adopts a "speak less, speak last" philosophy in leading town-hall meetings with employees. He will listen and learn rather than deliver long, slide-driven presentations.
"I won't take a position on an issue or I might take both sides of an issue and get a debate going," he said. "Our town halls are heavy on Q&A."

Brown likes to spark discussions by asking the group, "What's on your mind that you may be afraid to tell me?" or "Tell me some good news I don't know about." He responds to both live questions and anonymous emails.

To spur innovation, Brown encourages the firm's engineers and product managers to join firefighters and police on "ride-alongs." The company makes what Brown calls "purpose-built devices" for fire, police, military and other customers.
"Our systems are customized around the customer," he said. "The only way we can do that is to have firsthand knowledge of their business."

In designing a radio for firefighters, for instance, employees observed that firefighters often wear thick gloves so they need radios that are easy to use with limited hand maneuverability. In dark, smoky conditions, firefighters also need brightly colored radios.
To foster collaboration, sales, engineering and product design teams work together to innovate. Incentives flow from "team achievement for financial results and customer wins," Brown says.

"Historically, Motorola was known as a company of warring tribes," he said. With about 22,000 employees, Brown prefers to motivate staffers by cultivating a culture of teamwork.When you enter Greg Brown's office, you cannot miss the glass wall. Infinera (INFN) stock jumped Wednesday after Goldman Sachs upgraded the fiber-optic parts maker to a buy rating on views that the fiber-optics company's telecom customers will upgrade networks to 100 gigabit-per-second technology.
Shares of Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Infinera were up 11% in afternoon trading in the stock market today. The stock is about even this year with today's gain.
Goldman analyst Simona Jankowski forecasts better profit margins for Infinera as telecom companies upgrade long-distance networks to 100 Gbps fiber technology from 10 Gbps.

"We estimate 100G shipments currently have approximately a 15% point gross margin advantage relative to 10G shipments," wrote Jankowski. "We believe this may be due to a combination of a more rational competitive environment, fewer 100G vendors, and less pricing pressure given the early stages of 100G adoption compared to a mature 10G market.

"Infinera entered the 10G market in 2005, over five years after the market emerged, in contrast to ramping 100G within two years of the market's inception. Thus, we expect incremental margins on 100G shipments to drive overall gross margins higher as 100G increases from mid-50% of total product revenue in 2013 to mid-70% in 2014."
Jankowski wrote that she believes Infinera has regained Level 3 Communications (LVLT) as a customer.

IBD's Telecom Fiber-Optics group — which includes Clearfield (CLFD), Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI), Finisar (FNSR) and Ciena (CIEN) — ranks just No. 146 out of 197 groups tracked. It had been No. 2 six months ago.

Goldman, meanwhile, also upgraded Calix (CALX) to neutral from sell and downgraded Motorola Solutions (MSI) to sell from neutral.Infinera (INFN) stock jumped Wednesday after Goldman Sachs upgraded the fiber-optic parts maker to a buy rating on views that the fiber-optics company's telecom customers will upgrade networks to 100 gigabit-per-second technology.Shares of Sunnyvale, Calif.-based Infinera were up 11% in afternoon trading in the stock market today. Shares of corporate and government communications equipment maker Motorola Solutions (MSI) were up more than 5% in early trading Wednesday, after the company late Tuesday said its first-quarter sales jumped 7% to $1.96 billion, beating analyst views for $1.93 billion.
The company, which spun off from Motorola in January 2011, said revenue was buoyed by strong global demand for its products from government agencies in the U.S. and other countries.

Motorola Solutions posted adjusted earnings of 59 cents a share in the first quarter. That's up 9.3% from the year-ago quarter and 5 cents above the consensus estimate of analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.
For the current quarter, Motorola said it expects adjusted earnings of 65 cents to 70 cents per share. It expects revenue to grow about 6% from $2.06 billion last year, to about $2.18 billion.
Analysts are forecasting earnings of 68 cents a share on revenue of $2.1 billion.

The company said sales in its government unit surged 11% to $1.3 billion. But sales in its corporate segment fell 2% to $655 million.Shares of corporate and government communications equipment maker Motorola Solutions (MSI) were up more than 5% in early trading Wednesday, after the company late Tuesday said its first-quarter sales jumped 7% to $1.96 billion, beating analyst views for $1.93 billion.The company, which spun off from Motorola in January 2011, said revenue was buoyed by strong global demand for its products from government agencies in the U.S. and other countries.Motorola Solutions posted adjusted earnings of 59 cents a share in the first quarter. In the last five trading days, telecom stocks witnessed a sharp rise initially and maintained a flat trajectory thereafter as the Trump administration imposed tariffs on $34 billion worth of imported goods against China. The stocks resumed its ascent later in the week but slipped partially yesterday, as Washington issued a fresh threat to impose additional tariffs against the communist nation.At the stroke of midnight last Friday, the United States implemented its long- publicized trade tariffs against China, prompting a swift retaliation of the same magnitude by the latter. As the battle lines were drawn and shots fired from both sides, the U.S. equity markets remained more or less unfazed by the events and seemingly waited for one of the warring nations to blink first to avert any catastrophic damage. However, after Trump issued threats to impose an additional tariff on $200 billion of goods from China, equity markets became shaky and lost resilience.Amid this cacophony, the U.S. Commerce Department offered a window of opportunity for the initiation of trade-related negotiations with China, as it inked an escrow agreement with ZTE to move it closer to resuming its business activities. This would allow China’s second biggest telecommunications equipment manufacturer to start its normal production schedule with access to U.S. suppliers. The seven-year ban imposed on the beleaguered telecom firm in April would be revoked, post its deposit of $400 million in the escrow account.      Regarding company-specific news, technology collaborations, acquisitions and new investments for network expansion ruled the roost over the last five trading days.Recap of the Week’s Most Important Stories1.    Nokia Corporation (NOK  -  Free Report) inked an agreement with China Mobile Limited to carry out joint research to explore the potential of artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning in 5G networks in China.By collaborating with Nokia, China Mobile seeks to establish a laboratory in Hangzhou, China, to develop a demo system that will evaluate the feasibility of newer applications within 5G ecosystem and leverage AI and machine learning capabilities by working in tandem with third parties. This will help both the companies to successfully address the booming market of the digital economy. (Read more: Nokia-China Mobile Partner for AI Research in 5G Networks)2.    T-Mobile US, Inc. (TMUS  -  Free Report) has augmented its LTE coverage in New York City area by enabling CBS Corporation owned WLNY-TV to repack 600 MHz spectrum per the FCC mandate to clear spectrum for wireless providers.The freed-up spectrum will facilitate T-Mobile to better serve its customers in the region with 5G-enabled products and services. T-Mobile plans to use its 600 MHz spectrum holdings to deploy America’s first nationwide 5G network by 2020. (Read more: T-Mobile Boosts LTE Coverage in New York With Freed Spectrum)3.    Ericsson (ERIC  -  Free Report) has been selected by Italian telecom firm Wind Tre to modernize the latter’s Radio Access Network across the country.Per the deal, Ericsson will implement the Ericsson Radio System (ERS) product portfolio into the Italian communications service provider's network, starting October 2018. It includes new ERS Radios and ERS Basebands to enhance network quality and user experience for Wind Tre’s 31 million customers. (Read more: Ericsson to Transform Wind Tre's Network Experience in Italy)4.    Juniper Networks, Inc. (JNPR  -  Free Report) announced that ESDS has successfully implemented its high-performing networking solutions to enhance cloud application delivery for greater speed and scalability. ESDS is an India-based managed data center service and auto-scalable cloud solution provider.Juniper will power ESDS with cloud transformation as it creates a secure, scalable and automated multicloud environment for its customers. The company is simplifying the journey for customers toward a secure and automated multicloud. (Read more: Juniper Provides Improved Cloud Application Delivery to ESDS)5.    AT&T Communications, part of AT&T Inc. (T  -  Free Report), announced that it plans to acquire AlienVault to augment its line of cybersecurity products designed for small and medium-sized businesses. AlienVault is a privately held computer security firm based in San Mateo, CA.The buyout will synergize AlienVault's expertise with AT&T's cybersecurity solutions portfolio that includes threat detection and prevention as well as response technologies and services. After the acquisition closes, AT&T business customers will be able to access the unified security management platform that helps make organizations more effective at threat detection and response. (Read more: AT&T Unit to Buy AlienVault to Boost Cybersecurity Portfolio)Price PerformanceThe following table shows the price movement of some of the major telecom stocks over the past week and during the last six months.In the last five trading days, Motorola Solutions, Inc. (MSI  -  Free Report) was the major gainer with its share price increasing 3.7%. AT&T was the major decliner with its stock losing 2.6%.Over the last six months, Motorola was the best performer with its stock appreciating 19.7% while AT&T declined the most with its shares falling 15.8%.Over the last six months, the Zacks Telecommunications Services industry has underperformed the benchmark S&P 500 Index with an average fall of 7.7% compared with a decline of 0.2% for the latter.What’s Next in the Telecom Space?In addition to continued product launches and deployment of 5G technologies, all eyes will remain glued to how the tariff war reshapes the global trade equilibrium as the earnings season commences.The Hottest Tech Mega-Trend of AllLast year, it generated $8 billion in global revenues. By 2020, it's predicted to blast through the roof to $47 billion. Famed investor Mark Cuban says it will produce "the world's first trillionaires," but that should still leave plenty of money for regular investors who make the right trades early.See Zacks' 3 Best Stocks to Play This Trend >>

Ericsson (ERIC  -  Free Report) recently announced that it has been selected by Italian telecom firm Wind Tre to modernize the latter’s Radio Access Network (RAN) across the country.Per the deal, Ericsson will implement the Ericsson Radio System (ERS) product portfolio into the Italian communications service provider's network, starting October 2018. It includes new ERS Radios and ERS Basebands to enhance network quality and user experience for Wind Tre’s 31 million customers.ERS includes hardware and software for radio, baseband, power, enclosure, antenna and site solutions, the MINI-LINK portfolio for microwave transmission and a fully integrated IP router portfolio — all managed by a common management system. It has been designed to fit all site types and traffic scenarios, even as networks grow in scale and complexity across 2G, 3G, 4G, and 5G, delivering industry-leading performance on the smallest site footprint with the lowest energy consumption.The company has reinforced its ERS portfolio with a host of new radio products to support Massive MIMO technology to enable smooth evolution from 4G to 5G. It has also added a new category of radio products called Street Macro, a site type that addresses the need of operators to grow in dense urban locations.The company has delivered ERS with 5G-ready multi-standard solutions to more than 240 service providers worldwide since its launch in 2015. The installed base of ERS radios is capable of running 5G New Radio technology with a simple remote software installation, and the 5G RAN software enables first-movers to turn on 5G on new frequency bands.Ericsson’s strategic alliance with Wind Tre will bring the best radio access solutions across Italy. Also, it will help Wind Tre to deliver the best possible user experience to its customers in an increasingly data hungry and ultra-low-latency demanding market.In the past three months, shares of Ericsson have rallied 22.8%, outperforming the industry’s growth of 6.9%.        Ericsson currently carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ  -  Free Report) has joined forces with Hawaiian Electric, a subsidiary of Hawaiian Electric Industries, Inc. (HE  -  Free Report), to modernize Hawaii's power grids to better manage the increasing number of renewable energy resources and achieve 100% renewable energy objective. No financial information regarding the partnership was disclosed.For the first time, a utility firm will utilize Verizon’s existing 4G LTE network infrastructure for communication purposes specific to solar systems. The use of Verizon's technology will initially be limited to the Customer Grid-Supply Plus (CGS+) program. Its existing infrastructure and services will enable Honolulu-based Hawaiian Electric to accommodate CGS+ customers without compromising grid reliability.Verizon reportedly has the best cellular coverage in the state of Hawaii. The deployment of advanced meters with Verizon’s network capability is likely to start shortly. The capacity of the CGS+ program varies across Hawaiian Electric's service territories.This new partnership is solely for the CGS+ program. However, the use of Verizon's GridWide technology could be expanded beyond CGS+ customers. By using Verizon's GridWide technology, Hawaiian Electric will be able to detect and monitor the power moving to the grid from consumer-owned solar systems.The CGS+ program allows customers to export excess solar energy generated by their private rooftop systems to the grid throughout the day. Customers who join the program are required to use equipment for managing output and this is where Verizon's GridWide technology comes into the picture.Over the past three months, shares of Verizon have rallied 5.6% against the industry’s decline of 1.9%.         Verizon currently has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Though most investors believe that only risky stocks generate lucrative returns, it is not a rule of thumb. It should be noted that risky securities fetch handsome returns only when the market is bullish.We have created a strategy that shows that less-risky stocks can also generate impressive returns only when certain other parameters are considered.Understanding Beta Beta measures the volatility or risk of a particular asset in comparison to the market. In other words, beta measures the extent of a security’s price movement relative to the market. In this article, we are considering the S&P 500 as the market.If a stock has beta of 1 then the price of the stock will move with the market. So, the stock is more volatile than the market if its beta is more than 1. In the same way, the stock is not as volatile as the market if its beta is less than 1.For example, if the market offers a return of 20%, a stock with beta of 3 will return 60%, which is overwhelming. Similarly, when the market slips 20%, the stock will sink 60%, which is devastating. Screening Criteria:We have taken beta between 0 and 0.6 as our prime criterion for screening stocks that are less volatile than the market. But this should not be the only factor to be considered while selecting a winning strategy. We need to take into account other parameters that can add value to the portfolio.Percentage Change in Price in the Last 4 Weeks greater than zero: This ensures that the stocks saw positive price movement over the past month.Average 20 Day Volume greater than 50,000: A substantial trading volume ensures that the stocks are easily tradable.Price greater than or equal to $5: They must all be trading at a minimum of $5 or higher.Zacks Rank equal to 1: Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy) stocks indicate that they will significantly outperform the broader U.S. equity market over the next one to three months.Here are five of the 16 stocks that qualified the screening:Based in New York, G-III Apparel Group, Ltd. (GIII  -  Free Report) is the leading provider of apparel and associated products. The company beat the Zacks Consensus Estimate in each of the prior four quarters, the average positive earnings surprise being 190.8%. For fiscal 2019 and 2020, we expect the firm to record earnings growth of 46.9% and 12.8%, respectively.Urban Outfitters, Inc. (URBN  -  Free Report), based in Philadelphia, PA, is the seller of consumer products like footwear, fashion apparel for both men and women. The company surpassed the Zacks Consensus Estimate in the trailing four quarters, the average beat being 19.8%. Urban Outfitters will likely see earnings growth of 49.1% and 8.8% in fiscal 2019 and 2020, respectively.Based in Redwood City, CA, Genomic Health, Inc. Sierra Wireless, Inc. (SWIR  -  Free Report) recently unveiled the new AirLink MG90 high-performance LTE-Advanced Pro multi-network vehicle router, designed specifically to provide secure and constant connectivity for mission critical applications. This is the first device to be deemed FirstNet Ready.Understanding FirstNetTo better understand the motive behind Sierra’s newly-launched router, let us first talk about what FirstNet is. FirstNet is the nationwide public safety interoperable communications platform, which enables quick and efficient information sharing across disciplines and jurisdictions to improve situational awareness. This platform seeks to bring advanced technology to public safety agencies and first responders of the United States, and better manage time and critical information effectively. The FirstNet network is being developed by AT&T (T  -  Free Report) in public-private partnership with the FirstNet Authority.Unique Features of the New AirLink MG90Given the prime importance of the function of FirstNet usable devices, these are subject to numerous tests encompassing many aspects ranging from security and durability to network functionality. Only upon passing these tests, the devices are considered suitable to meet the public safety needs and certified as FirstNet Ready — a designation given by AT&T to Sierra’s new AirLink MG90 router. The router is based on the company’s AirPrime EM7511 embedded module. It boasts an extensive multi-network connectivity and offers a range of communication standards like dual LTE-Advanced Pro, Dual Concurrent Gigabit Wi-Fi and Gigabit Ethernet, with extensions to Land Mobile Radio and satellite systems. It also supports the 700MHz Band 14 spectrum, which is dedicated for public safety, with 3G fallback and integrated GNSS, delivering up to 600Mbps downlink speed and 150Mbps uplink speed.Sierra is a leading manufacturer of device-to-cloud solutions for the Internet of Things and has been providing mission critical communication capabilities for more than fifteen years. It has enabled public safety agencies to roll out reliable and cost-effective wireless solutions, winning the trust and partnership of more than half of the 100 best public safety organizations in the United States.AirLink MG90 routers supporting LTE-Advanced Pro and FirstNet Band 14 have been made commercially available through Sierra’s authorized channel partners, along with upgrading options for existing AirLink MG90 units that are already deployed.Price PerformanceIn the past six months, the stock has lost 22% against the industry's 0.8% rise. It remains to be seen whether the new first-of-its-kind device can take advantage of the powerful relationship with AT&T’s FirstNet network and rake in more revenues.Zacks Rank and Stocks to ConsiderSierra currently has a Zacks Rank #4 (Sell). Some better-ranked stocks in the space are Comtech Telecommunications Corp. (CMTL  -  Free Report) and Motorola Solutions, Inc. (MSI  -  Free Report), sporting a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy). You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank stocks here.Comtech has an expected long-term earnings growth rate of 5%.Motorola has an expected long-term earnings growth rate of 8%.Wall Street’s Next AmazonZacks EVP Kevin Matras believes this familiar stock has only just begun its climb to become one of the greatest investments of all time. Juniper Networks, Inc. (JNPR  -  Free Report) recently announced the expansion of its campus portfolio. The move includes the extension of Ethernet VPN (EVPN)-Virtual Extensible LAN (VXLAN) fabric to enable a common architecture for campus and data center fabrics. The EVPN-VXLAN protocol is ideal for campus architectures as it provides layer-3 transport with layer-2 capabilities.While EVPN is a standards-based technology that provides virtual multipoint bridged connectivity between different Layer 2 domains, VXLAN expands the Layer 2 network address space from four thousand to 16 million, largely solving the scaling issues witnessed in VLAN-based environments.Interestingly, enterprises can build campus networks, using the same protocols that are available today, with Juniper’s new EVPN-VXLAN campus architecture. By extending EVPN-VXLAN beyond data centers, the company is providing building blocks for an enterprise-wide fabric, which is a key component in building a simple and automated multi-cloud.  Juniper’s Branch PortfolioJuniper has enhanced its branch portfolio, with new capabilities in its Contrail SD-WAN solution, using NFX Series, SRX Series and vSRX Series WAN Edge devices combined with Contrail Service Orchestration. Contrail SD-WAN provides a simple and automated multi-cloud SD-WAN, which enables creating an evolvable architecture to simplify growth. It automates the WAN edge across Juniper virtual cloud endpoints and on-premises next-generation firewall. Contrail SD-WAN uses Contrail Service Orchestration to design and run the entire service lifecycle across NFX Series Network Services platforms, MX Series routers and SRX Series services gateways.Resell Agreement With Aerohive NetworksMoreover, at the same time, the company has expanded its alliance with Aerohive Networks, a global Wi-Fi leader, to provide a cloud-managed, wired, wireless and WAN solution. The global resell agreement with Aerohive will enable Juniper to provide a unified cloud managed campus and branch networking solution — from Ethernet switches to enterprise-ready wireless access points.5-Step Multi-Cloud Migration FrameworkJuniper is expanding its 5-step multi-cloud migration framework to include evolution paths for campus and branch networks. The migration provides enterprises with a set of best practices and natural technology insertions for easier completion of the journey to a secure, and automated multi-cloud.Share Price PerformanceOver the past three months, shares of Juniper have outperformed the industry, with average return of 12% compared with 4.4% growth of the industry.Zacks Rank and Stocks to ConsiderJuniper currently has a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the industry include Comtech Telecommunications Corp. (CMTL  -  Free Report), Motorola Solutions, Inc. (MSI  -  Free Report) and Ubiquiti Networks, Inc. (UBNT  -  Free Report). While Comtech and Motorola sport a Zacks Rank #1 (Strong Buy), Ubiquiti carries a Zacks Rank #2 (Buy). You can see the complete list of today’s Zacks #1 Rank stocks here.  Comtech has a long-term earnings growth expectation of 5%. In less than three years after its launch with much fanfare in October 2015, Verizon Communications Inc. (VZ  -  Free Report) has decided to discontinue its mobile video app Go90 from August this year. The strategic decision is largely driven by a lackluster business response from the Millennials, who are the primary target segment for the app.Go90 is a mobile first, social media platform that enables users to watch video content anytime, anywhere in the United States in a mobile device, regardless of the carrier involved. It features fresh content from top digital creators and offers a rich mix of sports, comedy, music, gaming, lifestyle, news and entertainment events.The app was specifically designed for the Gen Y audience of cord-cutters and cord-nevers, who either cancelled their multichannel cable subscriptions in favor of media available through Internet or never used commercial cable for television service and solely relied on Internet sources for video feed.Verizon expected to capitalize on this booming market through targeted video content and advertisements and reportedly invested nearly $200 million in its early stages. However, the company soon realized that Go90 was failing to gain traction despite wide promotional messages and engaging content. Consequently, Verizon laid off 155 employees who were working on the Go90 project in early 2017.In the meantime, Verizon acquired AOL for $4.4 billion in 2015 and all the digital assets of Yahoo in 2016 for $4.8 billion and merged these to create a new company called Oath in late 2017. With the formation of Oath, the sustainability of Go90 was at stake and it was put under the broader Oath umbrella.Oath is currently using brand advertising intelligence to help marketers build emotional connections with their customers through new 3D ad formats and first-in-market programmatic virtual reality (VR) ads. The programmatic VR enables advertisers to seamlessly extend existing display and video assets into fully immersive and consumer-first VR environments. On the other hand, 3D ads take brands to the next level by creating an interactive experience for customers, allowing them to explore objects and make informed decisions.With such rich ad formats and appealing video content, Oath has emerged as the prime business division of Verizon in this market. Accordingly, the company has decided to pull the plug on Go90 on Jul 31 and return shows and content rights to its production partners.In the past year, Verizon has recorded an average return of 13.9% while the industry declined 7.3%. The stock currently carries a Zacks Rank #3 (Hold). Better-ranked stocks in the space include Comtech Telecommunications Corp. (CMTL  -  Free Report) and Motorola Solutions, Inc. Ciena Corporation’s (CIEN  -  Free Report) converged packet optical solutions has been selected by Sify Technologies Limited . Notably, Ciena’s solutions will help Sify meet increasing customer demand apart from offering enhanced support for increasing data volumes, cloud-based services, the Internet of Things (IoT) and Big Data analytics.The deployment of Ciena’s WaveLogic Ai technology will enable Sify to scale its network capacity from 100G to 400G. Thereby, enabling Sify to provide ultra-high, data-heavy bandwidth services and manage unforeseeable traffic growth for its customers.Powered by WaveLogic Ai technology, Ciena’s Waveserver Ai and 6500 Packet-Optical Platforms will enable Sify to program its network to adapt to changing service requirements in real time. Moreover, Ciena’s PinPoint software will help Sify in solving potential trouble spots with accuracy apart from minimizing the risk of outages and accelerating repair times from days to hours. The company’s Blue Planet Manage, Control and Plan (MCP) software will also provide Sify with real-time software control.Existing Business ScenarioCiena is expected to benefit from rising demand for packet-optical transport and switching products, integrated network and service management software. Additionally, it is increasingly investing in the data and optical fiber market in order to cash in on the tremendous growth opportunity offered by rising bandwidth demand from network service providers. The company is also making efforts to expand its Web Scale IT Architecture in the enterprise market by launching products like new chipsets, metro architecture and mobile backhaul solutions. Ciena’s strong product portfolio is likely to boost its top-line growth over the long run.Furthermore, Ciena inked a definitive agreement to acquire Packet Design in second-quarter fiscal 2018. This buyout is likely to accelerate Ciena’s software strategy. Also, the acquisition is expected to contribute toward the company’s long-term financial goal of strengthening its Blue Planet and associated services business by approximately 14-16% annually over the next three years. The expansion of Ciena’s Blue Planet software business and network automation capabilities will provide the company with competitive differentiation besides improving its profitability.In the past six months, shares of this Zacks Rank #3 (Hold) company have rallied 24.6%, outperforming the industry’s 12.2% increase.Despite these positives, the company faces huge concentration risk as a major portion of its revenues is concentrated among a few large global communications service providers.
